 One of the most difficult aspects of your eager preparation and pursuit of . excellence in . contribution is getting so bogged down with the details of today that you fail to develop a sense of the future . Don't forget that you have a vision for the future.
 It is necessary that you be able to see the relationship of what you are now and what you will be in the future . It is quite necessary to see what you're doing now and now .
 Too many of us are prone to satisfy our whims of the moment without taking time to correlate the relationship of what we do now and its impact on our future . Too many people don't take time to understand the relationship between what we are doing now and what we will do now .
 It is often difficult to associate poor judgment today with the possible pattern of tomorrow . It is difficult to link poor judgement today with possible patterns of tomorrow, says CNN.com .
 A fairly common dictionary definition of the word ""advice"" is that it is an opinion recommending a course of action . A common definition of "advice" is that a person's opinion recommends a particular action . "Advice" should be an opinion, not an opinion .
 In the past few days, I am sure that every first year man at Bates has been given more advice than he can be expected to assimilate in what can be an extremely confusing adjustment period . I'm sure every first-year man has had a lot of advice to him .
 "I do not wish to take advantage of this opportunity to express myself by adding more words of advice, regardless of how good my intentions may be," says the author of the book .
 I would, however, point out that everyone who has already offered advice, or who will do so in the future, does so with a sincere desire to help . I would also say everyone who offers advice to help is sincere .
 The fact that advice on the same subject may prove to be contradictory simply points up the differences between the advisors as well as those of the advisees . The fact of the contradictory advice is simply a matter of fact that the advice is contradictory .
 These contraditions should act as agents to sharpen a college man's ability to make his own decisions and then to stand whatever criticisms will obviously come from those who differ in their thinkng .
 As an undergraduate, each man has, among many others, the task of learning to distinguish good counsel from bad, or helpful advice from the cynical remarks of the opinionated. The task of an undergraduate is to distinguish between good advice and bad advice, or good advice from bad .
 As in all aspects of college life, a high premium is placed upon a respect for truth and the development of sound judgment . The college experience is described as a college experience .
 There are few, if any, men who can provide a text, the mastery of which will provide an infallible way of attaining these goals . The text is a text that will provide a way to achieve the goals of your goals .
 I certainly have no intention of trying to . supply short cuts to the insights that must come from personal experience, although I am sure that in the course of the year I shall offer advice to many men in the class of 1966 .
 I would like to close by expressing the hope that each man in the first year class will take full advantage of the educational opportunity that will be his for the next four years . I would also like to thank each other for their efforts .

 Punting time allows punters time to down the ball within their opponent's 10-yard line . This rule allows the punters to be within the 10 yards of the field . Punters are allowed to be punted within the ten yards of their opponent .
 Downing the ball inside the 10 constituted a touchback, giving the ball to the receiving team on its 20-yard line . Previously downing the . 10 would have been a touch-back, instead of a touch back .

 The usual controversy about hazing has started again again . Hazing is seen as a transition period in the U.S.
 This largely sophomorefreshman activity, with the frosh assuming the role of underdogs, has been investigated annually by the administration and the two student governments .
 The rules about what the sophomores can and cannot do have tightened . As a result, the rules have tightened. The rules have been tightened.
 On the women's side of campus, hazing takes place in the dormitories only, with the exception of haze day, and only at a specified number of times . For example, on the female side of the university's campus hazing is restricted to the dorms .
 The rules about the traditional ""rearranging of the, freshman girls' rooms"" on the afternoon of Stanton Ride have been changed to avoid any destruction of property or excessive messing of rooms .
 While there were a few girls who became upset or angry about the spider-webbing and tissue paper, the great majority took the hazing in the friendly spirit .
 Hazing is carried on to help the freshmen become adjusted to the school . After all, hazing is carried out to help them adjust to life at the university .
 If further restrictions are placed on this orientation period, the purpose will be defeated . Moreover, if further restrictions were placed, they will defeat the purpose of the orientation period .
 Hazing now unites freshmen in giving them a common foe — the sophomores . Hazing is now uniting freshmen in a common battle against sophomorees .

 Texas Oil Draws Bates students . Money, for many of us, is often synonomous with that magic word, oil .
 This past summer, a friend of mine and I decided to discover exactly what was going on in the oil field . This summer, we decided to find out what was happening in the field .
 Parker Drilling Company is one of the largest drilling companies in the world . The company has major locations in Oklahoma, Texas, Boliva, and the French Sahara .
 Odessa, Texas claims to be the largest oil field supply center in the world, and I would not doubt it . Odessa is a major oil field hub in Texas .
 The city is bustling with construction companies, drilling companies, well services, roustabout gangs, pipe companies, and many more . The city has a reputation for being a tourist attraction .
 Work is largely a sevenday-a-week proposition, and an eight hour day in the field is too often an oddity .
 A Toolpusher is foreman on the rig, and beneath him are three crews . Underneath him is a foreman called the Tool Pusher . The rig is filled with workers from three crews.
 The men work 10, 11, and 12 hours a day laying pipe lines, fixing machines, and setting up the various pumps, belts, and drilling mechanisms . Until the crews ""break tower"" and start on the three eight-hour shifts, the men work eight, 11 and 12
 After a rig has started drilling, the work settles down to cleaning up the location . The work includes digging drainage ditches around the rig and adding pipe to the line .
 Roughnecks wash machines, paint, wash and paint the rig . The rig is often painted by roughnecks .
 We spoke to Roughnecks who varied in age from 18 to late 40's . Many roughneckers have roughnecked for 20 and 25 years . Roughneckers range in age between 18 and 40 years .
 San Cristobal de Las Casas — September 8, 1962 . Tomorrow I enter Guatemala for the third time . Crater's Edge is the final page of the book .
 Each time it becomes increasingly difficult to enter, to stay, and then return to Mexico . Each time, the situation has become increasingly difficult, to enter .
 Each time I feel more like a soldier of fortune and less like an inquisitive tourist, I feel less like a tourist . Each time we go to the UK, we are more like soldiers of fortune, not just tourists .
 "Even I wonder why I am returning. True, I am an incurable roman-* tic, but the ever present malignant threat is so real"
 The railroad runs through the jungle country, inhabited by Indians, drawn and malaria yellow, and climbs to the capital, Guatemala City . The railroad was built and controlled by the United Fruit Company .
 The road, when not washed out, runs through mountain villages to the capital . The road passes near two Indian trading centers, Huehuetenango and Chichicastenago .
 On a market day one can see Indians from many different villages . The people of each village wearing a costume, in color and design distinctly different from each other .
 The Spanish dressed each of the tribes this way to tell them apart . The Guatemalan government keeps them this way because it's good for the tourist business .
 In fact, it's the government's desire ""to keep things the way they are""; that is the cause, in part, of the heightening tension in this country . The government wants to keep things 'the way they're'
 Americans, with a traditional belief, until recently, in no large standing army, must take a grain of salt . This feature of every Latin American country is one which Americans must take with a grain, salt .
 A huge force of country and city police, alarmingly disproportionate to' mainland the Guatemalan population . But aside from these garrisons, there is a huge force . The Guatemalan police force is alarmingly .
 They walk the near deserted streets with sub-machine guns on their shoulders . They walk with sub machine guns on the shoulders .
 Two weeks ago three men jumped one of these law officers and shot him with his own submachine gun . The officers were shot by three men who jumped in front of him with their submachine guns .
 The people in Guatemala quietly rejoiced, while some in Mexico more audibly praised the act . Some in Mexico applauded the act, while others praised it .
 While it has reversed the government's land reform program, it has assured the world that, at the present, it is not at all considering a reincarnation of the Inquisition . The government has assured that at the moment, it does not plan to reinstate the Inquisition.
 The force which directed this government into power and was its main support, is no longer trusted . The C.I.A.A., the force which directs this government, no longer trusts the U.S. government .
 Russian and American businessmen have called The Alliance For Progress the greatest aid to American interests in Latin America since the Roosevelt Corollary to the Monroe Doctrine . The Alliance for Progress is called the most significant aid to the U.S. since the FDR-led Monroe Doctrine.

 Scotland Native Assumes Soccer Coaching Position at Bates . This year, soccer has reached varsity status at Bates.
 In the past years there have been various adults who have acted as advisors to the squad . This is the first time the England squad has had an advisor to the national team . The squad has been coached by adults in the past .
 Mr Somerville has coached a soccer team for the first time in his career . He has a wealth of knowledge about the sport, including how to play soccer .
 In 1923, Mr Somerville came* to this country from Scotland, where soccer is the biggest sport . In 1923 he moved from Scotland to the UK .
 When he lived in Scotland he played a lot of soccer . He played for several years in a soccer league in the greater Lewiston area .
 Mr Som gram was started in this state less than ten years ago . Now there are varsity squads at Colby, Bowdoin, Bates, and Nasson .
 Soccer has an advantage over its rival sport, football, because of the erville goes back to Scotland to fact that 14 is inexpensive to outfit a soccer team . He feels that in the future, soccer has a advantage over football, as of the future .
 Many schools may drop football as a sport because of the expense involved . Then they will have soccer teams soley, and then they will play soccer .
 Mr Somerville feels the team should have a successful season this year . Because of the strong finish the Bates team had last season, he feels it should be a good season .
 Almost every day, he took his sister's car, packed a lunch, and then went to watch a soccer match in the nearby area . He packed up a lunch and went to a soccer game almost every day .
 He is retired, his former employer being the Central Maine Power Company . He says he is retired .
 Mr Somerville has one son who is the assistant principal at the high school in Gardiner, Maine .
 He compares it some ways to our national sports like baseball and football . He compares the sport to the country's national sports .
 For example, he tells of the tremendous stadiums and the huge crowds of people that come to soccer matches .
 The junior teams are comparable to the farm teams in American baseball in that that is where the professional teams get their material . Below them are the junior teams, which are similar to the American farm teams .
 Mr Somerville also notes that some of the top professional players get salpries that would make Yogi Berra and Stan Musial envious .
 He cites the many high schools that have soccer in their athletic program . He cites many other high schools with soccer programs .
 He says Maine schools are an example of the progress soccer has made in college sports .
 Lloyd Lux, Director of* Athletics for Men since 1949, is one of the staunchest advocates and greatest benefactors of the Intramural Program at Bates . Lux has been the director of athletics for men since 1949 .
 This familiar figure has been ""sort of a jack-of-all trades"" in athletics . Most of the students are ignorant of his varied background .
 He began his coaching career at a high school high school in suburban Philadelphia . Dr. Dr. Larry King is a former Philadelphia high school coach . He has been in charge of the Philadelphia Police Department since 1984 .
 Lloyd Lux was head coach of football and assistant coach of basketball at Lloyd Lux University . He was also assistant coach at the University of Birmingham . Lloyd Lux also coached football at the university .
 Deciding to further his education he did work for his Master's Degree at Springfield College . Decided to further education he worked for Springfield College in Springfield, Illinois .
 At the time time he gained more coaching experience at Wilbraham Academy as head baseball coach and assistant football coach . At the . time time, he gained . more coaching . experience . At . time he . gained more . coaching experience . at WilBraham Academy .
 Lux returned nearer home to teach Mathematics at Moorestown while serving as head baseball coach, and assistant swimming and football coach . Lux returned to Moorestown to serve as head coach, assistant coach and assistant swim and football coaches .
 He began the swimming program at Moorestown High School; now one of the strongest in New Jersey . He began it at the age of 16 .
 His duties also included varsity basketball and the freshman football team .
 He found time to be head of the basketball and baseball program at the Jacksonville Naval Air Station . He also heads the baseball and basketball programs .
 He gained his first real taste of the intramural system, serving as the supervisor of Columbia's vast program . He served as a supervisor of the program at Columbia .
 In 1949 he came to Bates College in his present role of Director of Physical Education for Men . He came to the college in 1949 . He is now Director of physical education for men .
 Lux's greatest ambition at the moment is to improve the intramural program . Lux is aiming to improve its intramurals program by improving the program .
 He feels that a club system would enhance the idea of competition and would be a self-perpetuating system . The club system has been criticised in the past .
 This type of program has been highly successful at other schools and would tend to place the competition on an equal basis . The program is expected to be successful in the future .
 He feels strongly that the student body on a voluntary basis should try this club plan for a period of two years . The student body should try the plan for two years, he says .
 Lux feels that sports are not overly emphasized or deemphasized at Bates College . Lux says that sports is not over emphasized at the school . Lux: 'Sports are not over-emphasized' at Bates .
 Scheduling is always a problem and Bates has a much smaller male enrollment than most of the schools that it plays . Scheduling will be a big problem .
 Lux took pride in the fact that the athletes miss less class time than any other school in New England . Lux said the athletic teams do very well considering the limited amount of manpower and number of men on the coaching staff . Lux also said that the sports are very well done despite the limited
 Lux has served as the golf and tennis coach as well as the mentor of the now defunct junior varsity baseball team . Lux has also coached golf, tennis and tennis at the University of Columbia .
 His son spent the last three years at Andover where he played football and lacrosse . His father says he is proud of his son's success .
 Yale freshman is one of the candidates for the freshman football team . Now he is a freshman at Yale, he says he is looking forward to playing football .

 BATES COLLEGE, LEWISTON, MAINE, October 10, 1962 . Alumni Assn. at Bates College is proud of its achievements .
 Representatives of campus organizations meet with Alumni Secretary Hank Stred to plan Homecoming Weekend . Homecoming weekend will be held at Bates College of Technology . The University of Bates will host a variety of events throughout the weekend .
 On Friday, October 19, Bates Alumni will return to the campus for a weekend of greeting old friends, renewing acquaintances, and chatting over college days . Alumni from Bates will meet old friends and renew acquaintances .
 Each event, from the pre-rally round-up Friday, to the Thorncrag open house Sunday, has been planned so that friends will have many hours to talk with one another .
 Alumni Association has been working with students who are key members of campus organizations . Back-to-Bates week-* end comes to an end at the end of the week .
 Paul Sadlier '64 '64, representing the Chase Hall Dance Committee, is in charge of Friday evening's open house in Chase Hall . The Chase Hall dance committee will be holding an open house Friday evening .
 Holly Milius '63 and Les Jones '63, co-captains of the cheerleading squad, will lead the crowd in cheering the Bobcats on to victory over Middlebury's Panthers at the game .
 Immediately following the game, Kathy Pease '64 will greet students and alumni during the Women's Athletic Association coffee hour . Pease will greet alumni and students during the coffee hour.
 The Back-to-Bates dance will begin at 8:30 Saturday evening in the Alumni Gymnasium . Chase Hall Dance Committee will lead the event .
 Peter Gomes '65 and other members of the Christian Association have planned Sunday's Chapel Service . The service will be held at the University of Cambridge, Massachusetts .
 From 2:00 until 5:00 that afternoon, the Outing Club invites all to visit Thorncrag Cabin to socialize over cider and donuts . Neale Schuman '63, is a member of the club headed by Neale .
 The Reverend Robert L Cope, guest speaker, addressed Bates students in the first religious service of the school year, on Wednesday, October 3, at nine o'clock .
 Reverend Cope invited to Bates through the combined facilities of the Billings Fund, the Student Religious Liberals and the Bates Christian Association . Cope was invited to the campus by the students' Christian Association and the student Religious Liberals .
 His speech dealt with a serious problem in a world which takes life too much for granted . His speech was the first of a series of speeches to address the world's problems .
 He advised the gathering to slow down its hurried pace, to stop and savor every moment of the wonderful era in which it lives .
 He reminded students that life is too precious and short to waste, for just at the moment we discover the true meaning and purpose of life, like a Roman Candle, it sputters, and quickly dies .
 Cope commented on the richness and promise of our age of scientific advancement . Cope spoke of the richness of the scientific age of the 21st century .
 The Single Culture"" Tomorrow night, October 11, at 8:00 in the chapel, Bates* College will play host to Sean O'Faolain, Irish writer, critic, and Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Scholar for 1962-63 .
 His twoday visit to the Bates campus is being sponsored jointly by the Bates College Campus Lecture Series and the Bates chapter of Phi Beta Kappa .
 He will consider some of the dangerous implications in Sir Charles Snow's thesis and some unobserved elements in the artist and the scientist which makes a bridge between them of sympathy .
 Professor Robert Berkelman's English Composition class will be O'Faolain's next audience at 8:00 Friday morning .
 In 1954 he gave the Christian Gauss lectures on contemporary literature at Princeton, which were later published in his book, The Vanishing Hero . He also gave a lecture at Princeton in 1954 .
 O'Faolain's roots are deep in Ireland, and he has extensive travel both in Europe and the U.S. O' Faolain is a multi-million-year-old award winner .
 The Irish Revolution, in which he took part, is reflected in most of his work . He took part in the Irish Revolution and wrote about his experiences .
 O'Faolain is perhaps most renowned for his short stories and for his novel, A Nest of Simple Folk . He is best known for his stories, short stories, and his novels, including A Nest Of Simple Folk.

Farmington's top three students attending Bates College attain the highest combined general average during the academic year .  Avery's Peak will be the goal of Bates Outing Club mountain climbers on Sunday, October 14, announced George Hunter '63 and Judy Bradshaw '63, directors of hikes and trips .
 Bigelow, is located in Dead River Plantation in Somerset County, Maine . Bigelows is a plantation plantation . It was established in the 1800s .
 The mountain gets its name from Major Timothy Bigelow, who climbed the mountain under the order of Benedict Arnold during the march from Maine to Quebec . The mountain is named after the Major Bigelowe who climbed it under the orders of Arnold .

 Maine Pine land Seeks Volunteers To Aid Patients . Bates Christian Association was recently contacted by the Pineland Hospital and Training Center in Pownal, Maine .
 They have requested help in their program with the mentally retarded and handicapped children . The children's parents have also requested help from the government .
 I, as a CA member, visited the hospital last Friday to find out what their exact needs were . In an effort to learn what their needs were, I, a member of the hospital, went to visit the hospital .
 The fields in which help is needed are unlimited, according to the Institute of Science and Technology . The institute is dedicated to helping people in the fields of science and medicine .
 Premedical students can be of value in such fields as physical therapy, x-ray, and bio-chem. laboratories . Students can also learn in physical therapy and x-rays .
 Psychology majors can find a place to apply their knowledge in such things as giving tests or just working with children . Psychology majors will be applying their knowledge to the classroom .
 Students from Colby come down once a week to work at Colby . Elizabeth H Nevin, Elizabeth H. Nevin . Nevin: "I learned that students ... come to Colby to work"
 Most students return year after year because of the experience and enjoyment they get from helping these children . Students return to the school every year because they enjoy the experience they get .
 Pineland offers you a chance to help others and yourself at the same time . Pineland is located in Pineland, Georgia, and is located on the outskirts of Atlanta, Georgia .
 It is a job which must be kept up on a weekly or monthly basis in order to be of any value to you or to Pineland . Pineland.com will provide an example of the work done for you .
 The children become depressed when volunteers who are expected do not show up . They cannot use people who are willing to come on a haphazard basis, for the children . The children's school cannot use volunteers who do not expect them .
 There are many problems such as transportation and working hours which must be solved . There is no solution to the problems of working hours and transportation . There are also many problems to be solved such as transport, working hours .

 The 4< HOBB"" LAUNDRY SERVICE of ALL TYPES FOUR BATES STUDENT, Oct. 10, 1962 Editorials .
 Pride in one's college and the concomitant spirit has noteably been absent from this campus for these last few years . Pride in the college has been absent in recent years. Pride in your college is an important part of your college experience, says the president .
 The shadow of school spirit is emerging and taking shape in the shadow of the school spirit . Now in the growing glory of a successful season in football .
 "Perhaps as we raise our voices in criticism this coming year, we might also look within ourselves for the faint outlines of pride and concern for this college," the author says . "We might also raise our voice in criticism, but perhaps also find the faint outline of pride, concern for
 Ours has been a heritage of complaint directed against the institutions of this school . Ours have been directed at the institutions, this school has been accused of corruption .
 It is time that we look to ourselves for the heritage of pride and school spirit which we have not had. It's time to look back at ourselves for our school spirit . It is not the first time we have had a school spirit in our history .
 Our years here should not be spent in adding to the apathy that has prevailed. Our years should be spent not adding to that . Our years in the U.S. should not add to that apathy .
 We can take pride in Bates College only to the extent that we have confidence in ourselves as citizens of a college community which means something to us . Bates College is a small college in the heart of the nation . We are proud of Bates College. We are confident that Bates College means something
 As we bask and enjoy the success of our football team, let us realize that it is not upon the accomplishments of our teams that school spirit can be sustained . School spirit can't be sustained if school spirit is sustained by team success .
 For such sustenance is totally external and dependent upon our conquering of others, we must conquer others . For such a great thing is that we conquer others, our sustenance must be external .
 In your attitude, not as a class, a team, or any group, but as an individual, lies the extent to which school spirit shall emerge, take shape and prevail here at Bates . The school spirit will emerge as a result of the attitude of an individual .

 "The mess of gumwrappers, paper scraps, and whatnot is unnecessary, unbecoming, and frankly, embarrassing," the author says .
 Such litter is unnecessary because the college provides an adequate number of wastebaskets . Such litter was unnecessary because of the college providing an adequate amount of waste baskets, the college says .
 It's embarrassing because some students do care what impressions others receive of Bates . Bates says it's embarrassing that some students care about what they think others think about .
 "We have a beautiful campus and we must all help to keep it looking clean," says the university president . "We need to keep the campus clean," he says .
 Every gym class I am required to do something beyond my physical capability. Yet every gym class is required to be physical . I'm not a physically fit person, but I'm an athlete. I want to be a fighter, not a fighter .
 I am required to play games I cannot understand, do not enjoy, and cannot participate in with even the slightest physical dexterity or prowess . I'm required to participate in games I can't understand .
 And I am not alone in wanting to do something about improving my present physical state. And I'm not alone. I want to improve my physical state, I'm going to do it .
 "I do not think that the continually changing five week units are going to improve me. But, gentlemen, I do think that . I do . But I don't think that changing five weeks units will improve me," he said .
 This year I am floundering around on the football field — and while my attempts serve as amusement for my classmates and my coach, I feel that I am getting nothing of benefit from the activity . This year, I am . feeling that my attempts . serve for amusement for classmates and
 Rather I want a remedial gym class to take the place of my present class . I want to be able to learn how to use the gym again, rather than go to the gym .
 "I honestly think that I am too far gone physically to do much on my own without supervision. Of course, one might argue that could improve myself on his own, but I think that could not improve myself without supervision."
 "I would like to toughen up and become able to perform in a regular gym class with some confidence," she said . She said she wants to 'toughen up' and become more confident .
 "I think that the athletic department is failing to give people like myself a sane physical education program. And I think that . And I'm not going to be able to go to college," he says .
 I acknowledge the value of the athletic program and do not mean to detract from its place in the Bates curriculum . I do urge the department to recognize the fact that there are those students incapable of performing adequately in the standardized program .

 The simple and poignant Indian film ""Pather Panchali"" will renew far-away memories of childhood delights, fantasies, and sorrows .
 Satyajit Ray's "Song of the Road" is the first film of a Hindu trilogy . The film is written, directed, and produced in India . It is also the first of a trilogy of films by Ray . The trilogy is a sensitively and profoundly written and directed
 Ray, formerly a commercial artist, has used non-professionals, instead of stars, to capture the mist-filled joys and experiences of young, rural Brahmin children . Ray's work is based on the experiences of children in rural India . He has been using non-
 Apu and his beloved older older siscontrasted to and endangered by their rude, impoverished environment . Apu's beloved older brother and sister are also endangered by the environment of their environment .
 Daily their witness their poetic father and work-worn mother struggle joylessly in a never-ending effort to protect the family from the enveloping arms of poverty and starvation .
 Apu has been able to mirror and balance life's laughters and sorrows . However, in spite of the decaying society in which Apu lives, Ray has managed to balance his own life .
 The film is enriched by artistic and detailed photography, which enhances the universal appeal of the movie . Besides lyrical realism, this film is also enriched by detailed photography .
 ""Pather Panchali"" has been an award winner from Calcutta to the Cannes' World Film Festival . It's no wonder that the film has been awarded multiple award winners .

 Foreign governments see the United States as a giant power too weakkneed and hesitant to protect its own interests . This is because foreign governments, with foreign policies determined as they are by Machiavellian politics, see the U.S. as a weak, hesitant power .

 Psychology Club Hears Talk On Causes, Treatment Of Alcoholism . October 9, 1962 the Psychology Club had the first meeting of what should be an interesting year of programs .
 Mr Rowland Hastings of the Alcohol Counseling Service in Lewiston was the guest speaker . Mr Hastings was a guest speaker at the event .
 Mr Hastings, who graduated from Bowdoin and did study in the treating of alcoholics at Yale, discussed alcoholics and alcoholism in the community . Mr Hastings is a former Yale professor who studied alcoholics .
 Mr Hastings stressed alcoholism is a disease or behavior disorder that causes increasing problems in all areas of the alcoholic's life .
 There are ""alcoholics"" on the street who have never taken a drink, according to Mr Hastings .
 The causes are to be found in the psychological structurings' of the potential alcoholic . The psychological structures' of a potential alcoholic are to blame .
 Persons between 17 and 23 years of age are the most susceptible to this disease . Persons between the ages of 16 and 23 are most susceptible .
 There are five counselling centers in Maine with one located in Lewiston . One of the centers is in Maine .
 The alcoholic's spouse and family must cooperate with his treatment as well as often be treated themselves . In order for treatment of alcoholics to be successful, the alcoholic's family must also cooperate with treatment .
 Alcoholics Anonymous also runs groups for nonalcoholic spouses and for teenage children of alcoholics . Alcoholic groups also run groups for spouses and teenage children .
 A A. A. has been successful in 50% of its cases as compared to 2% rate of success by psychiatrists . Psychiatrists have a success rate of 2% success rate for A.A. A .
 Mr Hastings told the club that he felt himself particularly qualified to discuss alcoholism because he was himself a former alcoholic .
 Following the talk, as at all meetings, a question and answer period was held . The talk was followed by a question-and-answer session .
 Psychology club believes it has an interesting and varied program this year . The psychology club hopes to have an interesting program this season .

 These will be available during daytime hours from Miss Foster in the Library . Miss Foster will also be available in the library during the day .

 Any constitution, in order to embody this principle, must meet three definite requirements . Any constitution must meet these three requirements, including a constitution .

 As long as it effectively limits the power of government, it may be a constitution . It recognizes the Princple "not under man, but under God and the Law,"" as long it recognizes the princple .
 Constitutionalism provides a legal limit to arbitrary power, and, at the same time, permits a complete response of the government to the governed . This is the duty of Constitutionalism, writes David Frum .
 Judicial Review serves as a link between Democracy and Constitutionalism . The principal of Judicial Review is to be seen as part of the Constitution . Judicial Review has been a model of American democracy .
 The Court, through its interpretations of the constitution, can judge whether or not governmental action is within the limits imposed upon it by the constitution . The Court's interpretation of the Constitution is critical of government action .
 By adapting its interpretations to meet the needs of a constantly changing government and people, the Court ensures the growth and development of the democracy . The Court will continue to adapt to meet changing needs of the government .
 What remains to be done is to carefully examine the wording of the Constitution, to change and strengthen it where needed, to build a stable, workable, and sure foundation for the future .
 Committee on Graduate Study was established in 1959 to encourage more Bates students to undertake graduate study in applied as well as academic areas . Committee was established to advise the Dean of the Faculty concerning students to be endorsed by the college for non-departmental grants .
 The Committee's advisory function has been carried out by sifting academic, extracurricular, and other qualifications of students wishing to be endorsed by the college for the various competitive grants .
 Each candidate's objective and plans for attainment constitute an important influence on the Committee's judgments . This aspect has considerable weight in the decisions of the selection committees of the various foundations .
 The Committee's second function is to encourage more students to enter graduate study . Results come more gradually, but results come more slowly .
 Forty-seven percent of the men in the Class of 1961 actually did graduate work as against 43% in the . Class of 1959 . The Class of 1960s was the most successful class of men in history .
 The library has also established a separate collection of relevant books . ""A Guide to Graduate Study"" by Ness and ""Fellowships in the Arts and Sciences,"" are most valuable to a prospective student .
 The Committee's effort to make known available financial assistance is an effort to help the American Gem Society raise funds .
 Lewision ance was an important step but of interest only to those students who had already decided to enter graduate school and were in need of financial help . Students were able to apply for financial assistance to help pay for their education .
 In order to encourage more students to undertake graduate work the Committee has been pointing out the importance of this not only to the individual but to society due to the greater development of talents in whatever the chosen field might be .
 This has been promoted through assembly talks, Phi Beta Kappa sponsored meetings and the effort of individual faculty members . This is the result of the efforts of faculty members and students .
 Bates graduates may be in strong competitive positions within their respective fields . Graduates need to obtain specialized or technical training which generally entails graduate study for advanced degrees . Bates graduates are required to obtain advanced or specialized training .
 This is true not only for academic careers but in applied areas where specialization and tech nology are advancing so rapidly . This is especially true for applied areas such as technology and technology nology .
 Guidance and Placement Office is primarily in position to help students who do not plan graduate study and are seeking employment in business or secondary school .
 More than half of our seniors now hope to go on to some area of graduate study requiring detailed and personalized advice from some faculty member .
 A knowledge of individual students and the variety of experience required for sound advice is beyond the resources of any small committee or administrative group . A knowledge is beyond a small committee and administrative group can't afford to rely on small groups .
 Committee is providing each department with data concerning the undergraduate record plus what is known about the career plans of each of its senior majors . Committee will also provide data about career plans .
 There seems to be some hesitancy to become committed to becoming committed, as though a change in circumstances or new evidence would not permit a sensible change in plans .
 An early act should be to introduce the idea of graduate study to one's family . Discussing its purposes and importance with those whose encouragement will help even if financial support is unavailable .
 Another positive step is to read materials available in the library such as ""A Guide to Graduate Study"" by Ness . Another positive way to help students is to take advantage of the experience .
 Then seek advice from whatever faculty member one would enjoy discussing the matter with . Then ask for advice from whoever you want to discuss it with .
 If a faculty member feels unable to advise, he will undoubtedly send a student to someone else he believes is able to suggest appropriate undergraduate courses to take and graduate schools to apply to .
 Students sometimes put the cart before the horse by trying to settle the matter of financial support first . Students sometimes, and quite understandably, put the . cart before . the horse first .
 No one is interested in supporting a prospective graduate student lacking a clear objective and a reasonably well thought out plan concerning how he expects to attain his objective . But no one wants to support a student who lacks clear objective, a well thought-out plan .
 Those interested in graduate study in regular academic discipline in pursuit of either a master's or doctor's degree should seek advice from faculty members of the appropriate undergraduate department .
 Students interested in graduate study in non-academic areas should seek advice from faculty members who are interested, informed, or will help secure the kind of advice needed .

 By teaching English to Indian boys in a small district school in the Sierras De Oaxaca, my Spanish improved one hundred fold. By teaching  boys in the small school, I was able to learn English from Indian boys .
 Language was only a small segment of my education at Guelatao . But the language I learned in those two weeks was only one of many things I learned about .
 This small village was the birth place of Benito Juarez, the great president of Mexico . Juarez was born in a small village in Mexico's capital, Mexico .
 A full blooded Indian, born in poverty and obscurity, he led his country through one of its most trying periods . He was born into poverty and poverty and was born in obscurity . He led the country through a difficult period in the 1930s .
 A contemporary of Lincoln, he was often compared with the American president . He was a contemporary of Abraham Lincoln, often compared to him .
 I had come to Guelatao to learn about this man, but it was my interest in the people of this village which held me there. I had been there to study this man's work, but I was interested in his work .
 The Indian boys who live at this school are taught the fourth, fifth, and sixth academic grades and a craft trade . The boys are also taught the 4th, 5th, and 6th academic grades .
 The boys have to scrape out three years of schooling during their young lives spent working in their fathers' fields .
 Mexican students are permitted to enter a university after sixth year . After the sixth year, they are allowed to study in Mexico's universities .
 There is only one in about three hundred who ever gets that chance. However, there is only about one in three hundred of those who ever get that chance .
 Most of the rural Indians of Mexico are reared to a system which keeps them in the position of poor laborers and therefore, the lower strata of society . The system keeps them from being poor laborers .
 Many Mexicans profess that it is not the system and that the Indians are stupid . Juarez was a freakish exception. Many Mexicans say Juarez is an exception to the system .
 Zopotecs of Guelatao are intelligent and eager to learn, says counselor . "I have acted as counselor for adolescent boys for the last five years and I had never found a group as intelligent," he says .
 They learned and retained more English in two weeks than I did Spanish . They learned more English than they did Spanish. They were able to retain more English .
 Many were able to carry on ungrammatical and simple conversations with me before I left that village . "Many of the people in the village had never been able to talk to me," he said .
 There are several obstacles in the way of these intelligent and interested boys learning English, but the most pressing is the lack of text books . The most pressing problem is that there are no text books to teach English .
 To have studied another language is one step toward becoming another Juarez, Juarez . To study another language, it's one step to become a citizen of Juarez. It's a step toward the university.
 You will do a great service to Mexico, to our country, and especially to our fellow students in Mexico by giving them your old Spanish texts and dictionaries . Give them to your fellow students, especially to fellow students .

 Rumor has it that the Outing Club is looking for people who enjoy a view from the top of any of nine different mountains in Maine and New Hampshire .
 The Hikes and Trips directorship of the Outing Club is in charge of scheduling and supervising mountain climbs, ski trips, and canoe trips for the college . The club also supervises mountain climbs and ski trips .
 Washington in New Hampshire is the first campus-wide activity sponsored by OC in the fall . OC is sponsoring the fall activities at Washington University in N.H.
 This is followed by two more autumn climbs to such mountains as Tumbledown, Avery, Saddleback, Baldpate, Carter Dome, Baldface, and Old Speck .
 These are rotated on a four year basis, so within the usual period of college residence, it is possible to climb all eight mountains . The eight mountains are located in the U.S. National Park in Colorado .
 In the spring, the final mountain climb of the year is once again held on Mt. Olympus . The final climb of 2014 will be held on the mountain in the spring .
 The ascent is made only to Tuckerman Ravine because of the severe weather conditions encountered at higher altitudes . The climb is only made to the top of the mountain because of weather conditions .

 The Outing Club owns six fiber glass canoes which are stored at Cobboscontee Stream, about 20 miles from Lewiston, Maine .

 Today marks the opening of the annual WRJR-FM fund drive . Jon D Olsen '64 i si 9 Bates STUDENT, OCTOBER 17, 1962 FIVE .
 Each year the campus radio station finds it necessary to conduct such a drive in order to maintain the fine broadcasting quality of the past .
 WRJR does not receive support from the Student Activities Fee . It is almost totally dependent on student contributions . We ask you to dig deep during* the next ten days and support your Bates College radio station .
 Your contributions will spell the future success of WRJR . If funds are sufficient, WRJR will allow such extras as away coverage of basketball games .
 Last week saw the installation of this year's library display, depicting WRJR past and present . The WRJR library display was installed last week .
 Other big events in lower Pettigrew include a modernized control room, many new record albums, and much better news coverage .
 A steak dinner will be given to everyone in the dorm winning the WRJR Fund Drive competition . The competition is based on a competition between WRJR and WRJR .
 This is the ONLY way your station can raise the funds necessary to operate for the coming year . The only way to raise money is to donate to your local radio station .
 Representatives will contact you in the dormitories and in the Rand and Commons dinner lines . Representatives will be in contact with you in dorms, dinner lines and dorms . Reps will also be in the Senate and the House of Representatives .
 Dorm -scores are on a percentage basis, so the smallest dorm has an equal chance with the largest . Dorm scores are based on the size of the dorm .
 WRJR polled other college radio stations of comparable size to WRJR . None had operating budget of less than $1,500 per year . WRJR found that none of the stations had operating budgets less than that .

 This statement tends to give one the impression that existentialism is an organized school of thought that is peculiar to the 20th century, and that the term ""existentialism"" is a neat category with clearcut boundaries . This statement is thought to be an attempt to make it seem that
 Only one philosopher, JeanPaul Sartre, has openly called himself an ""existentialist" He then proceeds to explain what he means by the term by explaining what it means by it .
 William Barrett's study, Irrational Man, serves as an excellent introduction into the sources, influence, and significance of present-day existential writings . However, there is more to existential philosophy than Sartre .
 Barrett begins his book by naming writers and philosophers who are either directly or indirectly associated with existential thinking . Barrett also names philosophers and writers who are related to each other . Barrett's book is published by Simon Tisdall at the University of Oxford, Oxford University, London .
 One of the introductory chapters, ""The Testimony of Modern Art,"" is particularly interesting because of its examination of the nature and basis of modern painting and sculpture .
 Kierkegaard, Neitzsche, Heidegger, and Sartre are four major philosophers associated with existentialism . Barrett traces back the sources of existentialism in the Western tradition . Barrett discusses their thought at length .
 Barrett's analysis is nonetheless a valuable introduction for those who are unfamiliar with the respective philosophies, and is also a stimulating study for those already have a background of reading . Although it goes without saying that any talk about a philosopher is hardly a substitute for his actual writings .
 Irrational Man is a lucidly written book that is rich with ideas and insights . It is also a lucid and insightful guide to the world's most complex ideas .
 Any college student should find reading it well worthwhile and rewarding . We are only using different vocabularies that fundamentally and in the last analysis mean the same thing. We are not thought differently in any important sense .
 Of course, we do realize that there is a breach between these two headings, science and the humanities . Science and humanities are science and humanities, the author says .
 At odd moments these two groups hesitate and stare at each other across a chasm . The two groups stare across the chasm at odd moments . At odd times, these groups hesitate to speak .
 Thinking the same thoughts, they shrug and turn away, for they can't understand each other . They shrug and say, 'I don't know what I think'
 We all realize that such a chasm can't be carried too far, for they have many, many things in common . We're not alone, but it's a good thing to say: 'I'm not sure what's going on here'
 The man of culture extends to each side the gritty hand of common goods . Thus we can see riding down the middle of the chasm amidst tremendous dust .
 Let us not forget that even though these three are holding hands that they are still separate from each other . Even though they're holding hands together, they're still separate .
 From a careful analysis of this one discovers that science and the humanities are doing different things . Science and humanities do different things differently, says the author of the book .
 It would be folly to say that the scientists weren't doing science and the humanists, humanities, humanities . "It's not a matter of whether science and humanists are doing science," she says .
 This distinction leads to a consideration of the differences between the two in general . This distinction is based on the fact that the two are different .
 It is very difficult to tell whether a person is a scientist or a humanist by the clothes he wears . It is well established that today it is . difficult to . tell whether someone is a . scientist or an artist by the clothing they wear .
 Generally speaking, they are birds of a feather who haven't been able to flock together . They're birds of the feather who have been unable to flock .
 I think we can all agree that the real issue here is not what separates these two groups but what is the thing that joins them together . The real issue is what separates the two groups, not what makes them different, it's what they have together .
 The two groups are not threatening each other in the west but are together facing a greater and a graver threat . They face each other's greater threat than they did in the past .

 The main interest of the members is not to study art in the normal classroom sense of the word, but to practice it . Art is not a subject of study in the classroom, but practice it, says the club .
 The group's philosophy is that one learns to paint by painting, and this idea is no less true for sculpting, weaving, ceramics, or any other of the group's activities .

 Carnegie Contains Finest Telescope In Northern NE . Bates College owns the best telescope north of Boston .
 Carnegie Science Hall in revolving dome commands an excellent view of the heavens . Perched atop the new Carnegie science Hall in a revolving dome, it commands an impressive view . The new Science Hall is located in the revolving dome .
 Karl Woodcock, Professor of Astronomy, stresses the fact that the present location is ideal, and that there are no obstructions . The telescope was mounted in a small building where Page Hall now stands .
 The telescope was hand made by Mr Roscoe Stephens, of Kennebunk, Maine .
 The final result of his work is a twelve-inch reflecting telescope with a one hundred-inch focal length . The telescope is a 12-inch reflect telescope .
 It took Stephens two years to grind the mirror, which is the heart of the telescope . Stephens spent two years grinding the mirror for two years .
 Experts claim it is ""an unusually fine mirror,"" considering that there is a certain amount of luck involved in grinding a mirror of this type . Woodcock said experts claim experts say it is an unusually fine .
 Stephens donated the telescope to the college . It was mostly a gift from Stephens . The college paid a fee for the telescope .
 With a one-inch eyepiece, an object is magnified one hundred times . With a 1-half-inch eye-peaker, it's magnified two hundred times more than a half-inch . With an eye-witnesses, objects can be magnified
 The observatory is primarily for the use of the astronomy classes . It is also used by students at the University of Columbia .
 Woodcock states that there are plans to use it in physics classes in connection with the study of optics .
 There can't be no heat in the observatory because the density of the warmer air would distort . There can be no heating in observatory due to density of air .

 In the past two weeks, letters have appeared in ""The Student"" either in favor of or attempting to provide justifications for an invasion of Cuba .
 Both parties unwittingly pointed up a greater menace — abandonment of moralty in a quest for national power .
 As American citizens, we are committed to a number of ideals, among them freedom, the political equality of all men, and the right of the people of each nation to choose their own form of government .
 Many would claim that we are, in a way, also governed by a Christian ethical system . Many would also claim that Christian ethical systems govern us in some ways .
 As this is a debatable point, however, I shall not consider this aspect of the problem . I will not consider the fact that this is not the only reason for this .
 The freedom of man is not only an end, it is also a means, and a regulation of means . I doubt that Mr Boyd and Mr Foster are somehow aware of these ideals, but I do doubt that they have any understanding .
 We must remember that Cuba is a sovereign nation, no matter how distasteful that thought may be . However threatened we may feel by Cuba, we must remember it is sovereign nation .
 The Western Hemisphere is not the sole domain of the United States to go blundering around in as it wishes, regardless of the thoughts of the other inhabitants . We must also bear in mind that the Western Hemisphere isn't the only domain the U.S. wants .
 While we may encourage a democratic revolution in Cuba (and this I heartily advocate), we may not forcefully impress our will upon that of the Cuban people . The Cuban people are not strong enough to impose their will on their own, he says .
 America is not only a political power, it is also an avowed upholder of certain standards of morality and human dignity . America should be committed to the cause of human freedom, the author says .
 To answer this, we will have to ask ourselves what our reasons are for invading Cuba . The U.S. should ask ourselves why we invaded Cuba, he says .
 "I'm sure that Mr Boyd does not feel that our existence is threatened by Cuba," Boyd said . "I don't think that our survival is threatened," he said .

 In accordance with the styles of the twenties, dresses are characterized by straight lines and long waistlines . While skirts are of the ""knee-tickling"" variety .
 Dangling beads sparkle against luxurious furs and feathers . Cloche hats covering escaping ringlets and spit curls complete the illusion . Clockeys cover escaping ringletlets and spitting curls .

 Residents of Hampden County, Massachusetts, are eligible for the Walter S Barr Fellowships made available by the Trustees of the Horace Smith Fund . Residents of the county are eligible to receive a Walter Barr fellowship .
 The grants are for the scholastic year 1963-64 in the total amount of $5000.00 for advanced study or research . The grants were given to students in the same year as 1963 .
 As a rule, the fellowship awards will be not less than $1000.00 . They will be made for one year, with the expectation that they will be continued if it seems warranted .
 Candidates who look forward to careers of definite social usefulness are preferred . These careers might be in politics, in scientific research, in teaching, in the ministry and in other learned professions .
 The fellowships will be awarded on the basis of the scholastic records of the candidates, of financial resources available to them and of all other pertinent information . The awards will be given to students from around the world .
 Preference will be given to those who have not had previous professional experience, particularly those now in junior classes . Preference to those with no previous experience will also be given .

 The Bates C.A. offers an antidote to the pressures and anxieties of the times in its programs of weekly Wednesday evening vespers . As the academic period rears again its ugly but necessary head on the campus .
 The C.A. conducts vespers every week the college is in session . Students who want to escape from the noise of the dorm, the hush of the libe, or the confusion of the campus in general .
 The service consists of organ music, and three short readings designed to assist the worshipper in his quest . Organ music is played by organ music and short readings .
 The act of worship is as simple or complex as the worshipper himself wishes it to be . Here are the images of the most beautiful and most beautiful sculptures .
 Vespers was designed and initiated by Bates students some years ago to fill a need and provide an atmosphere in which the religious sympathies of the students could be expressed in the manner the student desired them to be expressed, an atmosphere not provided by any of the ordained services of the college
 This is still the primary function and purpose of the Wednesday evening services . The Wednesday evening service is still a primary function of the service .
 From time to time, all of us need to remove ourselves from the pressure of ""academic continuity" and ""Denism"", says John Defterios . He says he needs a bit of spiritual refreshment, not of the pulpit style, but of the personal form,
 Wednesday evening vespers' sole reason for existence is to offer this refreshment . Vespers will meet at 7 p.m. ET on Wednesday night .

 Garold Thumm spoke to the Government class on the nature of federalism, November 1 . Thumm: Federalism is a model of state sovereignty .
 Thumm described the federal system as a form of government characterized by a balance of political power equally distributed between the states and the central body . Thumm: Federal system is characterized by balance of power .
 Disputes arise between the state and federal government as to what powers belong to whom . It is almost inevitable that disputes arise between states and federal governments .
 A federal system is characterized by the existence of a written constitution and a court system to settle these power disputes . A federal government is characterized as a federal system with a constitution .

 More than 4,000 Volunteers are already at work or in training for projects in Africa, Asia, and Latin America . Volunteers have been volunteering for more than a decade .
 Plans call for nearly 10,000 Volunteers to be in service in more than 40 countries by the end of next year . Volunteers will serve in 40 countries across the globe .
 A major emphasis (faring the next year will center on community development projects in Latin America) A major focus will be in community development .
 Volunteers, who must be American citizens with no dependents under 18, receive two to three months of intensive training at an American college or university in the customs, history, culture, and language of the chosen country .
 Refresher courses cover the skills that the Volunteers will use on the job . Volunteers will be trained to use the skills they will need to be used to help in the field . Volunteers are required to take part in the training process of a volunteer .
 Additional training is generally given at the Peace Corps' training camps in Puerto Rico . The Peace Corps is based in the U.S.
 Volunteers serve for two years and receive a living allowance to cover housing, food, clothing, and other expenses, plus a termination payment of $75 for each month of service . Volunteers serve two years, receive a $75 monthly payment for each monthly service .

 Remick Remick Unites Teaching With His Duties As Pastor by PEGGY PARTRIDGE '65 . Topsham, Maine, is a small town of about 4,000 known for its race track track .
 Topsham has more than a race track, it also has a church, the* United Baptist Church of Top Sham .
 More people than ever have been flocking to the church . The church's budget has increased by $10,000 . There has been an increase of interest and participation on the part of young adults .
 The driving force behind this new development is a new, young, energetic pastor, the Rev. The Rev. Rev. Michael Wright . The Rev Wright is a pastor who has been in the church for more than 20 years .
 Mr Remick had already assumed his position in Topsham last year, when he was asked to come to Bates . With his enthusiastic outlook, he had already been asked to join the company .
 Mr Remick consented to teach on the Bates campus three days each week . Realizing the need for an additional philosophy professor at Bates to help relieve the burden of Professor Joseph D'Alfonso, Mr Remrick consented .
 Mr Remick received his first formal education at Eastern College in St. George's College in Maine .
 Remick became interested in philosophy during his high school years, motivated by participation in debates and the idea of what forms good argument .
 It was also during these years that he received his first taste of William Henry James . He was also given the opportunity to learn from his father .
 A study at Eastern Baptist Seminary in Philadelphia formed the next step in Mr Remick's education .

 Peace Corps is a government sponsored organization with a two-fold purpose . The Peace Corps was instituted by President Kennedy in 1963 .
 Its first objective is to help educate and increase the living standards of under-developed countries . It also aims to help raise living standards in the developing world .
 At present more than 4000 volunteers are working, or training for work, in many of the countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America .
 Plans are under way to increase the Volunteer staff to 10,000 members 1963 . Peace Corps has been highly successful, despite attempts to discredit it .
 Peace Corps aims to instigate a feeling of good will between the U.S. and the countries in which its members are working . Peace Corps is based in Washington, D.C. and San Francisco .

 Diplomats are necessary to communicate on the official diplomatic level, but connection with the people is needed if we are to stimluate friendly relations between the U.S. and foreign countries .

 Ironically, however, its solution is not one which lies beyond the reach of any one of us of slightly above average intelligence . Even average-intelligence can be reached by even average-minded people .
 It involves a pensive and altogether serious look into a certain rather nebulously defined, yet, at the same time, quite clear-cut and definite area of reference .
 "The inevitable solution is by no means hidden on some occultly inaccessible and foreboding summit," says the author .

 Lewiston Healy Explains College Policy In Selection Of Faculty Members . Sabbatical program and process of securing faculty members present mysteries to all but a few Bates students .
 Dean Healy: The process of selecting a new faculty member begins when the administration is notified of a vacancy . Administration is notified when a vacancy will occur within a department, he said .
 Next, the Dean of the Faculty inquires of the department chairman if he can recommend anyone interested in the position . The Dean then inquires the department chair if anyone is interested .
 Graduate schools are contacted and a list of prospects are drawn . Then follows a great deal of correspondence, in which graduate schools contact and a selection is drawn .
 In some areas, Bates College receives unsolicited applications, and considers these as well . Bates College considers these applications as well as unsolicited .
 Whenever possible, a personal interview is conducted with the applicant . Interviews are conducted with an applicant .

 This organization was set up in the early Twentieth Century by a large philanthropic foundation as a non-profit insurance program available only to teachers and administrators in private institutions .

 Ensign Eaton received the M.S. degree in Meteorology . He was Project Officer at the International Institute of Meteorology, Stockholm, Sweden, and assigned to the American Embassy there .
 Commander Eaton was Head of the Technical Readiness Branch of the Office of Naval Weather Service, 1957-1959 . He was Meteorological Officer on the Staff of Admiral George Anderson, Commander of the Sixth Fleet, 1959-1961 .
 He is currently Officer in Charge of the United States Weather Facility, Miami, Fla. He is responsible for forecasts to the operating forces .

 Field hockey, in its original form, was played by many men and even today, in many parts of Europe, men still play field hockey . Field hockey is still played by men even today in some parts of the world .
 Both games have teams with five forwards, three halfbacks, two fullbacks and a goalie . The game is very similar to soccer as both teams have five forwards and two halfbacks .
 The purpose in soccer and field hockey is to score goals — in soccer with the head or the foot — in field hockey with a hip-length stick . In field hockey, the goal should be scored with the hip or foot, in soccer .
 Forward line gets ahead of the ball without having at least three opponents between them and the goal after crossing 25-yd. line . Forward line can't be ahead of three opponents in the 25-yard box without having to be between the goal and the other side .
 In picking up a ball, a player can only turn to the right when he reverses its direction . A player only turns to the left when he turns the direction of a ball . A ball can only be picked up when it is picked up by a player in a position .
 The stick can only come as high as the player's waist — either in front or in back . The stick must be in front of the player or in the back of the stick . Sticks are only allowed to be in the front or back of a stick .
 The ball may not be hit off the ground high enough to be the occasion of possible injury . Dangerous Hitting may be dangerous to hit .
 When tackling, the person may not get between the ball and opponent possessing the ball . Obstruction — When tackling (taking ball away from an opponent) may not be between the person and the person possessing that ball .
 Free Hit — Opponent has a free hit to his forward line from the place where the foul was committed . Free Hit is a hit to the forward line . Free hit is given to the opponent from the point of play .
 Roll In — Opponent kneels at the side of the field and rolls ball (not more than one foot in air) to his forwards . Roll In is rolled in at the end of the match .
 These penalties are used for fouls occurring in area of cage (striking circle) They happen for various types of fouls . Long and Short Corner — These penalties were used for several types of incidents .

 Lerner was born in 1902 in Russia, the son of an itinerate teacher of Hebrew . Lerner came to the United States at the age of five and grew up in New Haven, Connecticut . Lerner is a Holocaust survivor and Holocaust survivor .
 He earned an A.B. in economics at Yale, and a Ph.D. from Robert Brookings Graduate School in Washington, D.C. in 1927 .
 During the '30s, Lerner was a quasi-Marxist (teaching at Harvard, Sarah Lawrence, Williams) and thought the U.S. ripe for Fascism . Lerner thought the United States was ripe for fascism .
 Five years ago, Lerner finished his 1036page paean, America As a Civilization . Lerner re-evaluated his adopted country, and five years ago he finished his book . Lerner: America As A Civilization is America's best-selling book .
 Some of his previous books include Ideas Are Weapons, Ideas for the Ice Age, and Actions and Passions . Some of the previous books have been published in the past .
 Bates College has filed a complaint with the Maine Public* Utilities Commission . Bates College is concerned about water rates established by the city of Lewiston . The college has filed the complaint against the city .
 "In so doing, it discriminates between classes of consumers and members of the various classes," the author says . "It discriminates," he says .
 Water meters have been installed in all buildings on campus, obtensibly as part of a program to be put into effect for all non-profit institutions throughout the city .
 The president and the trustees of Bates assumed that all such institutions were to be taxed equally . Bates was the first institution to have been taxed at the same rate .
 While the College's water rates have risen substantially, other schools, churches, and hospitals are paying reduced or merely token rates .
 President Phillips said the city has stated that it has a threeyear program to meter all nonprofit institutions . The city has said it has stated it has three years of meter meters .
 Bates filed a complaint to the Maine Public Utilities Commission . The commission has the right to regulate rates for non-competitive activities . The mayor has not given a satisfactory answer to Bates .
 "During the past several months we have tried in every way to avoid this step," he said . "We are very disappointed that we have not been able to find a solution to this problem"
 Water service will be disconnected by the city, residents say . Residents say they had 'no alternative' to having their water service cut off .
 Mayor Girard: College has been singled out to pay a higher rate while other nonprofit organizations are still paying the lower rate . As we wrote last August, "What we object to is that the College has ... singled out"
 Bates is not complaining about the increased water rates, but about the unfair application of this increase by the City of Lewiston . Bates is appealing to the Public Utilities Commmission, not the increased rates, he says .
 The Commission is expected to conduct an investigation and rule on the dispute . The Commission will investigate the matter .

 Throughout the world, many students live in deplorable housing and eat inadequate and poorly prepared food while attending school . Many students in the world live in poor housing and often eat poor food .
 Numbering about one million, the student population has more than doubled in the past ten years . Many acute needs are acute needs, including medical care for students .
 Almost all institutions of higher learning are located in the crowded cities and towns and offer very limited accommodations, especially food . Almost all of the institutions in the country are located near crowded cities or towns .
 Students from indigent families must spend limited budgets on food from catering houses . Food is neither well balanced nor prepared under hygienic conditions, but is costly nevertheless .
 WUS committees in India have decided to establish cooperative cafeterias . To improve the nutritional state of students within given financial limitations, several WUS Committees in India decided to set up cafeteras .
 Cafeterias will strive to provide good food at the lowest possible prices . Run by staff and students, these cafeterias are run by students and staff .
 The employment of students will help reduce administrative costs while allowing students to participate in the project . Students will be employed by the university in order to reduce costs .
 Nagpur is one of the universities which is badly in need of such a co-operative cafeteria . Nagpur University of Nagpur needs to have a cafeteria co-operation .
 A sizable percentage of Nagpur's 15,000 students live in private lodgings and have to depend for their food on public restaurants . Many of the public restaurants thrive only on student bills .
 The cost of starting this project will be about half of the drive's goal which is $1000 . The goal is to raise about half the $1000 goal .
 The money that Bates students provide will help give the Indian students at Nagpur a beginning, and through their own initiative and work student conditions will be improved . The money will be used to help improve conditions for the students in Nagpur .

 A joint meeting of Intergovernment Committee, Stu-C and StU-G, was held in Skelton Lounge . A meeting was held on Tuesday, November 20, at Bates College .
 The purpose of the meeting was to come to a decision regarding Bates' membership in the National Student Association . Bates was invited to a meeting to discuss the decision . Bates is a member of the Student Association at the University of Washington .
 Intergovernment reviewed Bates' two-year-long affiliation with NSA . Intergovernment had recommended that this affiliation be terminated .
 Stu-C members voted to support the Intergovernment proposal to disaffiliate . Following this, they voted for the disaffiliation .
 Stu-G members voted to postpone definite action on the matter of NSA and to continue the college's affiliation with the national organization for the remainder of this year . StuG members decided not to uphold the proposal, and voted to continue their affiliation with NSA .
 This brought any united action to a standstill, necessitated the joint meeting . This brought the united action at a standpoint and necessitated a joint meeting. This is the first time a united action has taken place in the past .
 Stu-C, in agreement with Intergovernment, believes that NSA has shown little ability to be of use in meeting Bates .
 The material distributed by NSA, when not entirely inapplicable to Bates' problems, has been insufficient to be of any real help . Bates: NSA material distributed to Bates is insufficient to help him cope .
 The high cost of membership in the organization is therefore unwarranted, and affiliation seems to be not only unnecessary, but burdensome . The high costs of membership are unwarranted .
 Bates has never given the organization an opportunity to do what it can . Bates has been criticized for not giving the organization a chance to help .
 By enlarging the committee of the campus NSA coordinator and making it more efficient, the full benefits of the organization could be realized . The committee should be enlarged and more efficient .
 Stu-G felt that membership in NSA should be continued for the remainder of the year, under an enlarged campus coordinating committee . For this reason, the committee felt that NSA membership should continue .
 NSA could be evaluated in light of what was done in their trial period . NSA could evaluate its effectiveness in the U.S. as a result of its trial period.

 Under team teaching, scnool personnel are grouped, with two or more teachers co-operatively planning and carrying out an instructional program for a group of pupils larger than that in a classroom .
 This plan is characterized by flexible grouping of pupils with all the pupils brought together for mass lectures and demonstrations and then split into small discussion groups . The plan is described as flexible and flexible .
 Whenever possible, the elimination of grade level designations allows grouping students of similar interests, abilities, or motivations . The elimination of grades allows students to learn from each other .
 Each teaching team will consist of a varying number of instructors, depending upon the situation . Students will be taught by a team of instructors at the school .
 Team Leader, who takes charge of the group, is an experienced and especially competent teacher . A Team Leader is a Team Leader who leads the group .
 The remaining part of the team consists of beginning graduate students . The team is comprised of students who have not graduated from college .
 Graduates and seniors from universities and state teachers colleges receive training in the teaching field as members of these teams . Students and seniors receive training as part of the teaching team .
 Teachers are selected on the basis of their predicted competence for teaching . They are selected for the role based on the predicted competence of their teachers .
 The executive members of the Bates Student Education Association attended the fall conference of all Maine college chapters of the S.E.A. held in Augusta .
 The purpose of this annual conference is to check the progress of each chapter in the various programs planned for the college year as well as to discuss and exchange ideas .
 Pappanikou is the acting Assistant Superintendent of the Pineland Training Center in Pownal . He is also the acting assistant superintendent at Pineland training center .
 Pappanikou lectured about the problems that confront the classroom teacher . He lectured on how to deal with the classroom problems .
 He explained difficulties that occur in teaching a group of pupils with widely varying mental intelligence, relating also the complicated situations which give rise to the emotionally disabled child .
 The speaker pointed out that the teacher, in dealing with these situations, must be an educator, a psychologist and sociologist .
 He also won Freedom of Information Awards from the Boston Press Club and the Capital Press Club . He concluded his remarks by discussing some current trends that are underway in primary and secondary education .

 The programs in Vienna and Paris are open to college sophomores and juniors, while the Freiburg program is limited to juniors . The programs are open in Vienna, Paris, and Vienna, and Paris, respectively .
