 Wright was once again able to observe from the student's point of view . Wright was able to see the student from his vantage point . Wright says he is proud of his students' success .
 Wright has been able to make some interesting comparisons between a thriving, throbbing, big-city university, and a small, friendly, co-ed, etc. university . Wright has also made a comparison between the University of Cambridge and a smaller, more friendly, more diverse city .
 Wright notes that students at Chicago seem more open to new ideas and have a keener sense of social concern . Wright: Students at Chicago are more open-minded about social concerns .
 Bates students come primarily from small New England towns, and have a more conservative background . Students come from a conservative New England town .
 Wright also feels that Bates students are more optimistic and have a little more ""good will"" toward each other . Wright feels that students are optimistic and more optimistic . Wright also said that students have more "good will" toward other students .
 Chicago students seem more interested in abstract ideas than Bates students, Dr. says . Bates students handle abstract ideas with more facility, Bates professor says .
 Wright and the girls especially bear a lesser burden of rules than their Bates counterparts . Wright is a junior at the Bates school . Wright says the girls are more likely to be allowed to leave the school .
 The library at Chicago is open at night attended only by student assistants . The stacks are always closed, except by pass, to prevent outsiders from wandering ' off with the books .
 With all their fine social connotations, the American Gem Society has a great social network . The Gem Society is an American Gem Club . The society is dedicated to its members, including the Gem Society .

 A great number of men in the student body wear some sort of accessory whiskers, and sloppy dress is the rule rather than the exception . The student body is full of men who wear some of their whiskers .
 Like too many city universities, the Chicago campus is run down and ragged . "The grass is trampled and littered, and the administration seems indifferent," the author says . "Like too many cities, the campus is ragged"
 Liberal elements (which make up most of the student body at Chicago) express themselves in many ways . The liberal elements of the Chicago University student body express themselves .
 The Maroon is printed several times a week and takes definite stands on controversial national and world issues . The student newspaper does not limit itself to campus affairs, but takes definite stances .
 Chicago professors often leave their classes in the lurch for several days at a time to attend conferences . Wright also found that the professors at Chicago are often less conscientious than Bates .
 Wright also noted an impersonality and lack of warmth not present to such an extent at Bates . Wright said the impersonality at Bates was not present at such a high level .
 Wright will continue his studies next year in India under a Fulbright grant . Wright will teach a course in Asian governments, and is planning to continue studying in India .
 "Beds are to be made and rooms straightened by 10 except Sunday and during exams," says schoolgirl .
 This rule is part of the dormitory regulations governing the appearance of women's rooms . The dormitory's dormitory rules govern appearance of the rooms .
 The house-mothers enforce this regulation by checking each girl's room every day, as part of their duties . The house mothers are also required to check each child's room daily .
 These are two rules whose place and value in the context of higher education I question . The rules are important to students, but I question their value in higher education .
 The mere existence of a rule which attempts to legislate neatness is a regression toward the conditions of a girls' boarding school . The mere . existence of the rule is a . regression toward a girls’ boarding school, says the author of the book .
 The rule is meant to be enforced by the way it is enforced in the U.S. State Department of Education .
 Students accepted with a certain understanding that they are mature and can accept responsibility . Students are accepted with the understanding they must accept responsibility for their actions .
 If they are not mature, then the college should enable them to develop maturity . If they don't mature, they should be encouraged to become more mature, says the author .

 Teams receive points in accordance with their final standings in their respective leagues, and in addition receive points for members of their dorm who compete in the interschool program .
 It is in this scoring system that the greatest fault with the present intramural program may be found . The scoring system is in the scoring system, the author says .
 A look at the standings at the close of the fall program reflects the inadequaces of the present program . The standings reflect the inadequacies of the program .
 Touch football scoring, as all intramural scoring, is based on the following system . Touch football scores are based on a touch football scoring system . The system is used in touch football .
 The A league winner receives 50 points, the B league winner, 40, and the C league winner gets 30 . The A and B league winners receive 50 points each .
 This division is the last place finisher's total . This total is divided by the number of teams in the league . The result of this division is this division's total of the teams who finish last .
 JB finished first and received 50 points, East Parker, Smith South, and Smith Middle . JB was the first team to finish first and receive 50 points .
 Middle received 12 1/, points on the basis of the division of JB's 50 points by the number of teams in the league . JB were awarded 12 1 / .
 The figure received by the last place finisher is then doubled, tripled and quadtripled to get the totals for the remaining teams in the league . The figures are then doubled and tripled to make up the total for the rest of the teams .
 On the basis of this system utilized in each league the touch football totals were derived . The touch football total was derived from this system .
 Three points are given to each of the dorm for each of its fall sports lettermen, two points for each sport varsity performers, and one point for each JV performer . The dorm would receive three points for its fall sport lettermen .

 Aristotle stood as the inheritor of the age of fear and the archetype of knowledge . If that is true, it becomes apparent that . Aristotle, as a quite characteristic Greek, although . of transcending intellectual ability, stood as . the transcending . intellectual ability .
 His function was to explain and rationalize the whole known world and man's relation to it . He was a rationalist who rationalized and rationalized the world and its relation .
 "His achievement was to sum up the ethos of a whole civilization more completely than anyone since him has been able to do," he said . His achievement was "to sum up [a] whole civilization," he added .
 Aristotle's God was for Aristotle not the supreme mystery, but the ""Unmoved Mover,"" the center of an orderly universe rotating about him . God was not for Aristotle to be a supreme mystery but a center of a dramatic universe .
 Only a people fearful of the irrational in them would thus make a fetish of order . He was thus, like the other Greeks, still operating in the shadow of fear, says historian .
 Aristotle was moving away from fear toward knowledge, which is a way of conquering fear, he says . Y e t t Aristotle moved toward knowledge as a way to conquer fear .
 His knowledge was chiefly of the external world, the beginnings of science without which the human being is fear-dominated, he says . He says .
 The Faustian impulse was not yet in him . But while he ransacked all the storehouses of knowledge open to him at the time, the Faustian impulses were not yet .
 Knowledge was for him a way of accommodating oneself to the world, rather than conquering it, as it was within the scientists of the seventeenth century . Knowledge is for him to accommodate himself and not conquer the world .
 The Greeks were caught between the assertion of will and the submission to law . Aristotle expresses it in his Metaphysics, between matter and form .
 Aristotle's method is wholly dialectical, characteristic of any age, like our own, it finds itself caught in so basic a dilemma . The method that is characteristic of an age, such as our own .
 Aristotle's rigorous analysis by the method of division and differentiation is increasingly suited to the temper of such an age, which seeks to find amidst the welter of change some firm ground on which it can stand . Aristotle's methods of division, differentiation are increasingly suited for this age of change .
 Third, and possibly last, we can develop an elan which will sustain an access to such wonderful possibilities . We can develop elan that will sustain the possibility of such possibilities. We can't wait for the future to see if we have the elan .
 The 61an itself will, of course, have to be possible, but this should not be particularly difficult if we maintain a general view .
 This view merely entails a commitment to the purely formal character of intelligence and thereby opens up for us a possible world . This view, however, does not mean that intelligence is not intelligence .
 This, mes amis, is the program — at least in its general outlines — so do not despair . Do not despair, you may yet find such a world possible .
 I seek not a possible world, but a real one and I see not an age of over-kill but one of under-live . "I seek not to be over-killed but to be under-lived," he says .
 In a refreshingly original and creative manner, he sets himself to the problem of coming to grips with the crisis that is confronting modern man, and does so in an informal way of Spanish wit . The book is published by Simon Cowell, a self-described Spanish journalist .

 He uses the idea of the generation, that there is an essential change of life in history about every fifteen years. He says that there are essential changes in life every 15 years .

 We haven't yet completely rejected the ideas of those who fought with Galileo, he says . But we haven't completely rejected those ideas, and it is this mixture of foundations that is causing all the confusion .
 "A historical crisis is when the world, the system of convictions belonging to a previous generation, gives way to a vital state in which man remains without these convictions," he writes .
 We are as our friend Jean-Baptiste insistedat the bridge, and the water is indeed cold, very, very cold . We are indeed as well as the bridge .
 FOUR BATES STUDENT, DECEMBER 5, 1962 Editorials . The art of fallout shelter building is secrecy . The ""sine qua non"" of fallout shelters is secrecy.
 Who knows but that those snobs at Bowdoin or Colby might wish to emulate Bates . Who knows that snobs might want to emulate him?
 Only the perverted mind might reason that it's sensible to construct a shelter in a maintenance building since it is maintenance equipment that will be first needed when and if anyone survives an attack .
 A maintenance building ideally serves as a fallout shelter provided that the term ""shelter"" is deleted from all of the blueprints save one . A maintenance building shouldn't be used to be used as a shelter .
 One has only to label the shelter area ""future storage area"" to silence inquiring minds . The shelter area has been labeled "future storage"
 A fallout shelter is just that, although Sarcophagus might be more appropriate . For, after all, a fallout shelter was just that .
 Disguising the shelter requires work, but may be accomplished with a certain amount of ingenuity . The shelter is located in the middle of a busy street in New Jersey .
 The walls must be reenforced after trucks parking in the building might strike the walls . The walls will be re-enforced, says the author .
 The walls will allow trucks to get nowhere near certain of the walls . Don't mention that trucks can't get into certain places .
 Shelter entrances must be so constructed to prevent radiation from entering, but still enable the shelterees to get in . Shelter entrances are so constructed that they can still be used to get into the shelter . The shelter entrances must also be designed to stop radiation entering .
 All entrances to the ""future storage area"" must be thickly walled and at right angles . Thus, all entrances to this storage area are thickly . walled .
 For the Bates ""future storage area"" has, not only thick walls and strange entrances, but a generator and a shower . The Bates ""Future storage area" has, as well as thick walls, has a generator, a shower and a bathroom .
 It undoubtedly is not significant to mention that the ""future storage area"" could not hold a thousand beings. It undoubtedly . It undoubtedly was not significant . The future storage area could not be held by a thousand .
 Perhaps it is not meant for much storage, only the administration, the faculty, and the high qpr's .
 Construct an artesian well between Hathorn and Hedge, large storage tanks, and the water problem is solved . Construct a well and a large storage tank for large water storage tanks .
 Convince the world that your fallout shelter is a maintenance building, and the battle is won . Convince yourself that you have a fallout shelter that's a maintenance facility, and you'll be safe .

 C I Am A Bobcat Back . The goal of a back on any one play varies according to the situation . C I am a Bobcat back .
 It is to pick up yardage on a long gainer, or pick up a first down, to set the ball in position for the next play, or to stop the clock by running out of bounds . It is also to set up a next play or set up the ball for
 From the many practice sessions the back has learned where to run and upon whom he can depend for a block . The back has also learned where he can run and how to block .
 If he isn't carrying the ball, he may block, fake, or run a pass pattern . He may also run a fake, fake or run pass patterns during the game .
 The men on the opposing team have their assignments which are designed to break up the play . The men from the opposing side have assignments which they use to break-up play .
 As the back approaches his position, he checks the defense to see how the hole will open up . The back checks out the defense before the play begins . The play-by-play video was posted on ESPN.com .

 On the snap of the ball, the defensive lineman may knife in so the tackle must block other than planned . The tackle must be able to block the offensive lineman in order to prevent the tackle being tackled .
 Back blasts through hole with his head low to avoid having a line bucker reach over and take his off . The back blasts through the hole .
 The advantage is with the ball carrier because he can cut, fake and cut, hit head on and dance, or hit and spin . The ball carrier can also hit and dance head on head on or head on, hit and head on .
 At all times the straight arm is useful, and when combined with varying speeds the back can make his own breaks . The back can also make its own breaks when using his straight arm .
 In the last analysis, what is needed is a block, a little finesse, and most important of all — desire . In the final analysis, it is needed to be a block and a lot of desire .

 Professor of Music D Robert Smith will present an organ recital on the Chapel organ on Tuesday evening, January 29 at 8 at 8 . Program selection contains classical and contemporary works designed to display the many attributes and aspects of the chapel organ .
 The works of Sebastian Bach, Buxtehude, and other masters of the 18th century provide a marked contrast to the vivid contemporary compositions of Marcel Dupre and Jean Langlais .
 Henry Purcell's Sonata For Trumpet was recently discovered in the Library of England's York Minister . It reflects the great heights reached in the art of trumpet playing in the Baroque period .
 The trumpet soloist, James Hureau '66 is also a rather recent discovery on the campus . Hureau is a recent addition to the University of Cambridge .
 Hureau has participated in a variety of musical endeavors . Hureau is a native of Stoneham, Mass., and a member of the band .
 He continues his musical life in the Bates Choral Society, and in the Concert and Marching Bands, as well as frequent appearances with Bob Cassaday .
 During the Second World War, Professor Smith gave weekly recitals on the outdoor organ in Balboa Park, San Diego for patients of the naval hospital .
 The Pacific Island of Espiritu Santo was his next assignment, and there, the organ by contrast was a portable harmonium . The organ is a portable instrument .
 Following the war, he returned to Puget Sound, coming to Bates as Assistant Professor of Music in 1950 . He returned to Bates in 1950 and was assistant professor at Bates .
 His musical studies have continued at the Peabody Conservatory, and at the famous Organ Institute at Methuen, Mass., as well as two European periods of study .

 Rob Players Present French Film Friday . "A Nous, la Libert*" is a bizarre but joyfully lunatic study of two ex-convicts .
 Director Ren* Clair has utilized the camera for emotional expression, keeping dialogue to a lean minimum . The film is set in New York City, New York .
 Music and song replace words in this satiric tale . Scarcely a speech is more than two sentences, as music replaces words .
 The film is a combination of fantasy and realism — somewhat like a weird dream — farcial, ironic, ironic and sometimes mystifying . The film was released in December .
 The central figures, Louis and Emile, make careful plans to escape from prison, but only Louis gets away . Louis is the only person to get away .
 Louis, a shrewd individual, becomes, under an assumed name, managing director of a phonograph factory . The success of the factory is based on ideas Louis got from the prison factory . Louis becomes a manager of the phonograph .
 Emile is released and finds a job in the phonograph factory, unaware that his prison pal is managing the plant . Louis soon hears of Emile, but he doesn't want to recognize him . Louis is a whimsical, dreamy sort of fellow .
 The two old friends have a ""high"" old time. Finally, however, he takes Emile into confidence and he takes him into confidence . Emile and Emile have a 'high' old time .
 Many sequences follow about their activities and the abortive romanee between Emile and a pretty co-worker . The film is set in Paris, France, at the end of the year .
 "The tale is lucid, but the manipulation of incidents is sometimes another matter," the author says . "The story is lucid but it's not always clear when it comes to manipulation," he says .
 M Clair's enthusiasm for the action of the picture causes an occasional lack of clarity . Characters brought on with more concern for the effect of the episode than for continuity .
 St. Clair never misses an opportunity for a satirical stab or a touch of irony . The book is set to be released in September .
 The skillfully developed comparison of the prison and the factory presents the numbing regimentation of the workshop in which theoretically free men perform the monotonous and unvarying function which binds them as inevitably as their convict fellows to the mechanical world .
 The prison is changed into an industrial enterprise; and the monotonous effects continue, with the former prisoners now laborers .
 As the film ends, Louis, having been threatened with blackmail, abandons the business . Louis is threatened by blackmail, having to abandon his business . The film ends with Louis having to be forced to leave the film .
 Boston Museum Treasures From For the first time, selections from the richest royal tomb of antiquity can be seen in the Western Hemisphere . Boston Museum treasures from the rich royal tomb will be shown in the region .
 From February 1 to March 3 the Boston Museum of Fine Arts will present more than thirty pieces from the tomb of the boy King Tutankhamun . More than 30 pieces will be displayed at the museum in Boston .
 Tutankhamun reigned for nine years, from about 1351 to 1343 B C, and died before reaching the age of 20 . He reigned from around 1351 B C to about 1343 A C .
 His tomb, with its more than 2,000 treasures, was discovered virtually intact in 1922 . His tomb was discovered in 1922, with his tomb virtually intact . The tomb is believed to contain 2,200 treasures .
 The opening of the royal mausoleum, which had been undisturbed for more than thirty centuries, gave the modern world its first glimpse of ancient Egyptian art and crafsmanship .
 It has been possible to see these treasures only in the Egyptian Museum of Cairo . It is now only possible to visit these treasures in Egypt .
 A selection of Tutankhamun's treasures have been allowed to leave Egypt and tour North and South America . Nubian monuments are threatened with inundation by the Aswan Dam . The government of the United Arab Republic has permitted a selection of the treasures to go on tour .
 The exhibit included rings, amulets, pectorals, and collars of sheet gold and feyance taken from the king's body . Royal King Tut's Tomb orite hunting dagger, fashioned of gold and found enclosed in the mummy's linen wrappings .
 Also on display at the Museum are collections of Egyptian art, considered the finest outside of Cairo . The Museum has been in Egypt for over 40 years .

 Miss Libbey reports that first semester grades should be available next Tuesday . She has international performances to her credit .
 Two seasons ago she went to Poland for a short stay, but attracted so much attention that she was offered a recital at the famed Warsaw Philharmonia . She was offered an engagement by the state music agency for a tour of Polish cities .
 Her mother was a concert pianist and her father was an operatic coach . Her father held 80 U.S. patents on inventions . Olegna was an opera singer and composer .
 Miss Fuschi became adept in both of her parents' fields . She still treasures a tape recording made when she was four years old on which she sings ""Vissi d'arte,"" the bravura aria from ""Tosca" and accompanied herself on the piano
 The direction of Miss Fuschi's career, however, soon became evident and the piano won over singing . The future of her singing career became evident in the early years of her career .
 Until she was twelve years old, Miss Fuschi continued to study exclusively with her mother .
 During her teens, Miss Fuschi studied as a starlet at the 20th Century Fox studios, but successive acting teachers there died shortly after she came under their tutelage .
 She eventually decided that it would be better for her morale if she gave up all thought of a dramatic career .
 Miss Fuschi also won the Juilliard Scholarships, the Josef Lhevinne Memorial Award and the Concert Artists Guild Town Hall Award . During the years with Madame Lhevne, she won the school's 1958 concerto competition .
 As Durrenmatt is to the modern German theatre, so is Hesse to modern German novel . Hesse is to be to modern theatre, and so is to modern novel, as is to theatre .
 Two of his novels, The Journey to the East and Siddhartha, are the impressions of a European who went to the east and incorporated Eastern culture . Two of these novels are The Journey To the East, Siddharth .
 The style of this book reflects the author's internal dialogue with himself . The style is simple, uncluttered, and honest, reflecting the author .
 Hesse was strongly influenced by The Little Flowers of St. St. Mary's The Journey . The Journey was written by Hesse himself .
 Brother Leo, the Franciscan, is very close to the servant Leo of the League, which is a brotherhood of men who pursue their individual destinies, and are bonded together by a common Truth .
 The trial of Joseph K is alluded to, as the narrator, ""Self-accuser H."" is put on trial as a consequence of his infidelity and lack of perception and understanding . The trial is alluded .
 Hesse deals with the despair of H H. Hesse . The Judge concludes that it is not the actual sins that are bad, but that fact that H is unaware of these sins . Hesse concludes that H H.'s sins are not his faults, but his .
 It is when the mutable and arbitrary are perceived by the self as universal and distinct truth, and, like Joseph K. K., when the individual comes to depend on outside authority and assistance to provide direction and strength, he has committed a sin which is not aware of, but of
 The picture is one of despair, and H H. H. is melted away into unreality, into nonexistence . The picture was one of the despairing moments of H H.'s life .
 He does not have wisdom, even at the end of his trial — like Joseph K. K., he can only see what is happening to him, and that only dimly . Joseph K.'s trial is not over .
 In Siddhartha, Hesse presents his problem again, but with a different man . The film is set to be released on Blu-Ray Ray Ray Rayne in October .
 It is the Brahmin's son, the god-like Siddhartha who pursues the journey, and the difference is that he is already in the East . The Brahmin is already there, but he is not seeking the journey .
 In his spiral path towards awakening and sublime consciousness Siddhartha goes through many self-imposed trials because of his selfaccusation . In his path to awakening he goes through several trials because he is self-confessed .
 The dominant theme that Hesse seems to pose again is the transitory world of the senses is illusion and that reality is the immutable unity which is in all things — the Truth of Om .
 It is the understanding that everything has in the germ of the divine, everything is an end. It is an understanding that . everything has . in the germs of the . divine . Everything has in an end, everything must end .
 There is an Eastern paradox of freedom and fate: Siddhartha sees that he has an irrevocable destiny, but also has infinite freedom within that destiny . Siddharththth sees he has irrevocably destiny but also freedom within it, says the author .
 His awareness is a revelation arising out of a continuous process of progression and regression . His awareness comes from a process of progress and regression, he says .
 Out of the realization that he is completely alone, that the subjective understanding and wisdom of the Buddha can not be communicated to another subject such as himself, that ""opinions mean nothing"", that he must see the wisdom within him, — out of these he achieves his own Nirvana

 Recent enrollment trends have finally caught up with Bates . Applications for September 1963 admission are below the levels of previous years . The admissions process is scheduled to begin in September .
 This is in accordance with a temporary national trend which other selective institutions have felt for the past three or . four years . This is the result of a national trend that has been felt by some selective institutions .
 Bates might have experienced such a decrease last year had it not been for the publicity which the school received from its General Electric ""College Bowl" appearances . The school received publicity from its appearances .
 The nation-wide decrease in college applicants stems from the low birth rate of 1944-1945, which has made for a smaller number of high school graduates . The decrease in applications, however, presents little problem to Bates .
 It is felt that most of the applications not received would have come from students of either low ability or of a caliber which would win them acceptance to more highly rated institutions .

 The full-time fellowship carries with it a stipend of $2,000 . It includes practical on-the-job training, plus theoretical study . The fellowship is required for a full time job .

 Dean Emeritus Harry W Rowe gave a talk to the Chapel assembly last Friday . Rowe Addresses Ch apel Group on Hathorn Hall .
 Dean Rowe's theme, the changing face of Bates as exemplified by Hathorn Hall, emphasized the expansion of Bates from a wooded pasture area with one building to the present elm-studded forty-building campus .
 Hathorn served initially as the college; housing the chapel, commons, and theater, as well as classrooms . Hathorn was built in 1854, and is located in Hathorn's original location .
 As Bates has expanded, the various uses made of Hathorn have correspondingly diminished . Hathorn has been used in many of Bates' most famous works .
 Hathorn serves only one of five buildings housing classrooms . Hathorn is now one of only five buildings in Hathorn's former campus .
 Rowe was a former Assistant to the President, Bursar, and the first Dean of the Faculty, Dean Healey . Rowe is now the College Historian at the University of Cambridge .

 Only once throughout the en tire performance did the listener feel that the exception rather than the rule was an integrated part of the performance . "En tire" is the first time the band has played in a public performance .
 There was an unshakeable sense of restraint woven throughout the first half of the program . There was also a sense of respect throughout the performance .
 Bach and Mozart were rendered more as warm-up exercises than entities unto themselves . Mozart and Bach are more than just warm-ups exercises than individuals unto themselves.
 The opening bars of the ""Appassionata"" remind one of Beethoven's Fourth Piano Con certo in which the almost crushing power of the orchestra is ar rested by the assured gentleness of the piano .
 Miss Fuschi found it difficult to maintain the duali ty which music of this type de mands. She said it was a difficult task to do .
 The assurance and agility with which she commanded the keyboard proved her a more than able interpretor . She was a 'more than able interpreter'
 The wrathful demands of the Scherzo were met with comparative ease . The vivacity of the Mazurka in C sharp minor with its varied rhythmic patterns was satisfying . The composer's solo solo solo was the first time he had a solo solo .
 The Etude is perhaps Chopin's greatest form of musical expression . Chopin had an elegant grace and beauty all its own . The Etudes are perhaps the most beautiful form of music ever recorded .
 Despite a few highspots, Olegna Fuschi's concert last week was, for the most part, unsuccessful . Vivian Leigh plus 'LOVES OF SALAMMBO'l limilllllll. WIIIIIUIIIIII IIIIII
 Her highly romantic style just does not suit Bach's intricacy and delicate tonal arrangements . Bach's intricate tonal arrangement is not suited to her romantic style . Bach is a highly sensitive classical musician .
 She started playing before the audience had quieted down and consequently the first few notes were lost . The audience had to quiet down before she started playing .
 Miss Fuschi apparently did not have contact with her audience's mood, and hence her playing became mechnical, and failed to produce any real response .
 Only the last variation sounded like Mozart, and she handled this one with a delicacy and taste which was lacking in the earlier sections .
 One cannot capture Beethoven with one's fists, but Miss Fuschi persisted through his Sonata in F Minor to attempt this task . She said: "One cannot capture him with one of his fists"
 Two different schools of music, the Baroque and Romantic . Her trill became uneven in her passion, and there was little note . The studentry was able to witness two different styles of music .
 To judge the Romantic period on the basis of Fuschi's recital, however, would be unfair to the composers involved . It would be a great mistake to judge the romantic period, however .
 At the Olegna Fuschi concert, the pianist seemed to have evaluated her audience . This is something which a politician should do, but never an artist, she said .

 It increasingly seemed, however, that the dramatic device which had gotten out of hand had got out of control . It was not the first time the device had been used .
 In her encore, she made hash of the Spanish baroque composer Soler; and would have probably done so to Bach at the beginning of the program were it not for the fact that such a lovely and simple piece as Jesu is hard to kill .

 Hureau succumbed to a couple of poor attacks in this demanding piece . Fluffs can always be forgiven, but a sustained inadequacy (as in Fuschi's performance) is much more discouraging .

 In the final movement, she lost most of her fervor, and it came out sounding like a well-executed Czerny exercise . The final movement came out of her final movement .
 Miss Fuschi managed to strike a balance between technique and romanticism in her Chopin selections .
 Chopin used modern harmonics to achieve his minor effects in the Mazurka and Etude . It was interesting to note how Chopin achieved his minor harmonics in these works .

 The withering sickness of perfection-lost-lost is a recurring theme in this new series of films .
 For a while, be it a split second or a considerable length of time, love seems perfect . Love seems perfect and fulfilling in itself, says the author .
 After the zenith there comes the pause where reality sets in for the world's first time . But there comes a pause in time when reality is set to hit .
 Stekel, in his book Auto-Erotism tells us (or at least presents us with a theory) why this is so .
 He calls love a projection of the self onto a loveobject or another person . Love is projection of self onto another person, he says. He calls it a projection .
 When our projection or idealization of the love object breaks down, we feel incomplete — and love dies . We feel incomplete when our projection, idealization, is broken down . When our idealization is broken, love dies, it dies .
 Since another person cannot be exactly like us, he/she must eventually assert his/her conflicting aspects . The reason for this is quite simple, really, really . Since we cannot be like ourselves, we must assert our conflicting aspects, this is the reason .
 The perfection we knew when the self-projection was complete lingers with us . And yet the perfection we know when the perfection is complete lingered with us. And yet, yet, it still lingers .
 It can be in the form of a Haydn symphony which reminds us of long black hair and first love . Or of a walk alone through a familiar neighborhood which we took a year before with our current love .
 I am making things sound ex tremely scientific, and love is not so mechanistic . Love is not about mechanistic, and it's not so scientific, I say .
 Stekel's theory may be true or it may be false, but still it remains that love and its loss produce phantoms which stalk us and seek to turn us to sorrow .
 "Never is one more completely alone than after the loss of love — of unity," writes Hillary Clinton . Clinton: Never is one less alone than when one loses love .
 Then one can only turn inward and die in the disjointed world he sees there, he says . Then one must turn inward, he writes, "and die"
 They see nuzzling, laughfilled talking, and sex as the only components of an ideal relationship . Nuzzling and laughterfilled talking are the only parts of ideal relationships, they say .
 Stekel would call them too much filled with triviality to be capable of completely giving over of the self to divine emotion . Stekel: "I'm not sure if I'm going to be able to completely give over the self"
 Most of mankind is like Bartleby the Scrivener who does not even recognize his ability to love . Most of humanity does not recognize its love, says the lawyer in Bartlebeby . The lawyer is a lawyer who doesn't even recognize that he loves .
 Wilhelm Reich, in his book, The Sexual Revolution, echoes the cry of Erich Fromm in The Art of Loving when he says that man is becoming disabled and is being forced into a form of emotional stasis by his highly repressive society .
 Those who know the sorrow of ""total love lost"" are becoming more and more alone in this society of loveless people . And those people who know "total loss lost" are becoming alone in society .

 For the economically minded who favor reducion in our military stock-piling, the above problem can be partially alleviated . The economically minded should be relieved of the problem .

 In our model society disarmament is possible as long as alternative actions are immediately available for continued government spending . In this model, disarmament could be possible if government spending is not found to be a problem .

 One guard and one forward from each team is allowed to ""rove,"" or cover the entire court . That is, one guard and a forward, from each side are allowed to "rove"
 The number of dribbles has been increased, therefore making a much swifter game . The game has been improved since the introduction of the dribble rule .
 No longer does the play return to center (i.e., a pass from the official to the center forward) after each basket . The play no longer returns to center after the basket .
 An opposing guard takes the ball out of bounds at the end line after each field goal . Instead of a field goal kick, the ball is taken out of the field at end line at end of line .
 No longer is the ball ""dead"" after a foul shot, but if the basket is missed, then the ball is instantaneously put into play . The ball no longer is "dead" after foul shot . If a basket misses, the ball can now be put in play .

 A Buddhist monk from Ceylon, at Bates for Religious Emphasis Week, spoke in the Chapel on Thursday, February 7 . Betty Bates Selection Buddhist Leader Explains Faith; Shows Its Role In World Peace; shows its Role in World Peace .
 His speech, entitled ""Buddhism and World Peace"" traced the origins of the religion as well as clarifying its customs and role in world peace .
 It does not require that its followers believe in a Supreme Creator, ritual, prayer, or worship . It doesn't require belief in the Supreme Creator .
 The Buddhist religion had its origin in Northern India during the 6th century B.C. when it revolted against the accepted practices and beliefs of the time and the Indian caste system .
 Buddhism disappeared from India and spread to the countries of Burma, Ceyion, Cambodia, Vietnam, Viet Nam, Laos, China, and Japan . Buddhism also spread to Burma, Vietnam and China .
 Today the Buddhist population includes 15,000 followers in England, 20,000 in Germany, and 170,000 people in the United States .
 From a meager though dedicated beginning of five persons, Buddhism has grown into a religion encompassing one-fifth of the world's people . Buddhism is one of the most important religions in the world, Buddhism .
 The founder of Buddhism was Siddhartha Gautama (563-483 B.C.), an Indian prince whose father was ruler of a small province in Northern India . Siddharthththam is the son of a king who ruled a province in India .
 Siddl hartha was raised in luxury and well-educated, yet at the age of 29 he renounced everything into which he had been born in order to search for a way of life that would bring happiness .
 Siddhartha and his followers spread his philosophy of life so that by the time he died, the Buddhist religion became an important influence in the lives of all it reached . Siddharth's followers spread the philosophy of Buddhism to all who they reached .
 This path consists of right belief, right resolve, right speech, right conduct, right occupation or living, right effort, right contemplation, and right ecstasy . This path includes right belief and right resolve and right conduct .
 Truman Grant Madsen spoke last February 8 about the Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter Day Saints . Madsen: The Buddhist does not blindly accept these Competitors for Betty Bates Title Madsen .
 President Madsen analysed the factors in their religion which are responsible for this community spirit . He presented a picture of the active community spirit of the Latter Day Saints .
 For the Mormon, God is pictured as the Eternal Father — literally the Father of the human family . The Mormon, for example, is seen as God's Eternal Father . God is also pictured as a father of the family .
 God is not an abstract concept but is, instead, a person, glorified and radiant . God is God, not abstract concept, but is a person who is glorified, radiant .
 A second concept basic to their religion is that of Jesus Christ as a man, the son of Man . not identical either in substance or in person with God with God . Jesus Christ is not identical with God, not identical in substance, or with God in person .
 To his people he is Redeemer, Lord, Savior, and, most important, Revealor . He is a man who had powers beyond those of most men .
 The Spirit of God demonstrates its presence through the love, peace, and faith of mankind . The spirit of God is revealed in the form of love and peace .
 This Spirit can manifest itself in the persons of men of the Latter Day Saints . This Spirit is manifested in the person of men in the church .
 Closely related to this idea of the Spirit of God is the Mormon picture of Man . The Mormon image of man is similar to that of the spirit of God .
 Each man, | as an offspring of God, has within him the embryonic traits of diety . Rather, each man, . as a . offspring of . God, he says . Rather than an offspring, each . man, he has within . him, he writes .
 "Every single human being has, within him, a tremendous potential for good," says CNN.com's John Sutter.com .
 No matter how evil a man may appear, these "seeds of divinity" may still make themselves known . President Madsen called them the "seeding of divineinity"

 Two strains of Hindu religious thought, termed monism and theism, have been extensively developed . Theism and monism are the two strains of religious thought .
 The monistic school, based on the ancient Upanishad writing, claims the existence of a semi-personal god . Man's primary goal is merger with this being, says the school .
 ConViction is the belief that no individual is ever completely alone, beyond hope . Accompanying it is the hope that no one will be completely alone .
 "Spirit is at peace since it is all-inclusive and therefore is in no need of change" "God, the Father, is always within man. and man may yet redeem himself"""; spirit is at rest since it's all inclusive .
 Hindu theism has modified Hindu monism and the teaching of the Upanishads to a belief in a personal god, Krishna, who is directly concerned with man . Krishna is a Hindu god who is concerned with the human body .
 Salvation does not entail disappearance of the individual in a total merger with God, as in the Upanishad tradition, but consists of communion between God and man . Salvation means communion between man and God, not disappearance .
 The importance of the two existing traditions lies not in the truth of one and the falsity of the other, says Hein Hein . He concludes that the importance of each tradition is not in its falsity .
 He suggested that perhaps no religion can encompass God as He actually is, but each individual concept is an honor paid to the true God .
 He discussed Christianity, emphasizing that fears and prejudices must be broken down . He said Christianity must be accepted by man being subject to God alone .
 Reverend Handspicker began by examining the essence of Christianity . After an introduction by Sandy Prohl '64, he began examining Christianity .

 National Review Publisher Speaks This Sunday Night at 8:00 in the Chase Hall Ballroom . William A Rusher, publisher of the National Review, will discuss the probable 1964 presidential nominees this Sunday evening . Rusher will also discuss the likely 1964 candidates .
 Rusher's visit on campus is sponsored by the Young Republican club . Rusher will also address Monday's Chapel assembly on U.S. domestic policy .
 Rusher has served as publisher* of the National Review, one of the nation's leading conservative publications, since 1957 . Club President Anderson emphasized that not just club members, but all interested students are invited to Sunday night's discussions .
 Both he and the magazine believe that a strong conservative sentiment exists in America . This trend will greatly influence such important facets of politics and government as the next presidential election and future domestic policy .
 He has made four trips to Europe in the past four years, covering almost every country on the continent . He has visited almost every continent in four years .
 Recently he returned from a tour of Africa, which he says increased his understanding of the battle for survival which freedom and communism are fighting in Africa .
 He served as associate counsel to the United States Senate's Internal Security Subcommittee in 1956 . He was associate counsel for the Senate's internal security subcommittee . He served in the Senate from 1956 .
 In this capacity, he participated in hundreds of public and secret hearings concerning the communist menace in America . The hearings included hundreds of hearings concerning communist menace .
 In October 1956, he went to Honolulu to prepare for the hearings there, and in November of that year he was sent to Austria by the senate on a special investigatory mission .
 Rusher, who was born in 1923, received his A.B. at Princeton, William A Rusher majoring in its school of public and international affairs . Rusher is the son of former President George W. Bush .
 After three years in the Air Force he entered Harvard Law School, where he received his law degree in 1948 .
 He served as a member of the Executive Committee of the Young Republican Nationtional Federation . Also during this period he served as member of Executive Committee .

 Efficiency Called For Efficiency should be achieved in spending money allotted to defense . Defense spending should be more efficient and more efficient, says President Obama .
 Defense Department should act to maximize output as private industry acts to maximize profit . Defense Dept. should act as private industries act to maximise profit, says Sen. Tom Coburn .
 Maximization of output will give greater efficiency, and as I said last week, greater efficiency means that decision makers who are better equipped to handle defense problems can be employed . Maximization means that decisions can be made to deal with defense problems .
 It should be noted that a difference exists between optimum and efficient maximization . It is also noted that there are no guarantees of optimum or efficient maximizing .
 Any point along a firm's (or in this case, the Defense Department) production function is by definition a possible efficient scale of production . The U.S. Defense Department says it is working with the U.N. to make the most efficient use possible .
 Now along these possible efficient points an optimum position may be located . The optimum position should be located at an optimal position .
 In this case the optimum point is defined in terms of the higher level criterion of minimum cost, given the factors of prices . The optimum point in this case is defined as the minimum cost of minimum .
 An inefficient alternative can be inferior to an inefficient one . SuZANNE: Substitute can be superior to an efficient alternative . SuzANNE is the name of the author of this article .
 When comparing alternatives the efficient and hopefully the optimum one is always preferred . When comparing an alternative to an alternative, the best is always the best .
 RAND Corporation economists have favored the policy of ""suboptimization" to mitigate efficiency problems in the Defense Department . RAND Corporation has favored the practice of "partial equilibrium analysis" or partial equilibrium analysis .
 They optimize alternatives at an intermediate leve because there is no way of de fining what they call a ""globa optimum" - the highest possi ble objective . There are no ways of fining the highest possible objective .
 The commander of a fighter wing who controls several squadrons has the job of maximizing the tota capabilities of his squadrons . Further up the latter the air de fense sector commander is in charge of several fighter wings, missile battalions, radar units etc.
 He must maximize the tota capabilities within his sector . And so it goes. He must maximise the capabilities within the sector .
 If national objectives change new criterions for decisions are required for the choosing of al ternatives . Economists Useful If National objectives change .
 This replacement of criteria, either because they are not optimal or they are outdated because of changes in technology and objectives, is a very serious matter for the Defense Departmentment .
 RAND publication states there is a range of circumstance in which policy improvements are available through the substitution of a better scheme of suboptimization criteria, but in which it would not pay to make a formal change in the de cision structure .

 Verne Ullom, head coach of basketball and tennis and football line coach, was the Garnet Athletic Department's choice to temporarily replace Coach Peck . Coach Peck is expected to return to the Bates staff at the conclusion of his sabbatical year in Finland .
 A four-year football, basketball, and baseball standout at Hughes High School in Cincinnati, Ohio . L Player L Player .
 Ullom was contracted to play professional football for the Brooklyn Dodgers . The Brooklyn Dodgers were an early N.F.L. team from the 1930s .
 Ullom then returned to Cincinnati where he accepted a position as a teacher and coach in the public school system . He then went back to Cincinnati, Ohio, where he was a teacher .
 His first real coaching opportunity developed at Taylor High School in North Bend, Ohio . He spent eight years in charge of football, basketball, baseball, and track .
 North Benders will never forget the high standard of athletics that Ullom established at Taylor . North Bender was a standout athlete at the time . North will always be proud of the high standards he set at Taylor High .
 Taylor produced three AllLeague football teams, an AllState baseball team, and three All-League basketball teams . His last four years at Taylor were the most impressive, during which time he won 52 out of 58 games played and finished one season undefeated .
 The following year, he became varsity end coach and then defensive line coach . He has been at the University of Alabama since 1984 .
 The year 1956 saw Ullom at Bates coaching Bob Hatch's line, varsity basketball, and J.V. baseball . Bob Hatch was coach at Bates High School .
 Bates won a Maine Series Football Championship and took a second to Colby in Maine basketball competition . During his two-year stay, Bates won two Maine Series football championships . Bates also won a second Maine Series Basketball Championship .
 Ullom's next stop was Principia, in Elsak, Illinois, where he was Athletic Director for two years . He was also Athletic Director at Principialia in Illinois .
 In 1961, he was at Columbia, coaching the line of the eleven that tied Harvard for Ivy League honors . In 1961 he coached the line that led the team that won the Ivy League title .

 The hard simplicity and genuine passion is somewhat shocking to American audiences, who have become used to the slick Hollywood studio productions . The hard-simmering film is a classic classic, but it is not a Hollywood classic .
 This film tells its story in a frank, uncompromising way, very different from what spoon-fed, sheltered audiences are accustomed to . The film tells the story in an unflinching way, unlike many other films .
 The anger is not hysterical, but the clear anger of those who have known the depravity of their foes . Anger not hysterical. Anger of those with knowledge of depravity will not be hysterical, it will be the anger .
 The cruelty of the enemy, the passion of life in the underground, and the intensity of the conflict are depicted in detail and with realism, the film is said to be the most realistic portrayal of the war .
 The producers are obviously anti-Fascist and anti-Nazi, and this determined feeling against the Germans and their collaborationists pulses through the film .
 More than anger, the film expresses an admiration for people who fight for freedom's cause . The film expresses more than anger than anger at people fighting for freedom .
 The film shows a real sense of human fortitude — a quiet exultation and an inconquerable belief in life . The film is based in New York City .
 The story of the film is literal based on actual facts of the occupation of Europe and of the underground resistance . The film is based on the actual facts that happened during the occupation .
 A leader of the resistance is the central character of the film, and is cornered by the Germans in a part of R""ome . The film is based on the story of a German resistance leader .

 He fought in the Second World War as a Russian tank commander . He was captured and put in a concentration camp by the Nazis . He fought as a tank commander and was put in concentration camp .
 As a refugee, he came to the United States, in 1952, and became a naturalized citizen in 1957 . He was born in New York City, New Jersey .
 Goncharoff's talk was based upon examples of his life under Communism . The major portion of the talk was about his twenty-four years in the Soviet Union .
 When 13, in 1933, the peasantry were ""resettled"" — scattered far from their homes . The peasantry was scattered far away from their home .
 They rebelled against this treatment, and the government sent troops to put down the rebellions . The government was forced to put the rebels down, and troops were killed .
 When the troops refused to fire on their own friends and relatives, Stalin withdrew all supplies, and people began to starve and die . Stalin withdrew the supplies and ordered the troops to stop shooting .
 Eight to ten million lives were lost, and his mother's was one of them . His mother's life was lost in the World War II .
 When a national purge began on the week before Easter, 1937, security police arrested his brother . Security police arrested him when the purge began in 1937 . His brother was arrested on the same day .
 A note came for Goncharoff from the government, congratulating him from being ""liberated"" from his religious brother . Gonchoff's religious brother was a member of the government .
 They are idealistic, and their desires to receive liberty and to break the bonds of peasantry were what excited them to follow the revolution of November 7, and Marxism . The revolution was the ""essentially spiritual promises"" of the revolution .

 Probably at one or more points in a college career a student considers transferring to another academic institution . By JENNIFER WINGATE '64, students may consider transferring to other institutions .
 The reasons are many — dissatisfaction with courses, financial difficulties, and personal problems, to name a few . The reasons for students to take up courses are many .
 As one student expressed it, "I would like an environment which is completely different. I would like to have a completely different environment"
 This desire for new blood is evident in these rather bleak months when we are haunted by the disappointments of last semester and are apprehensive about the evercoming school threats . This desire is particularly evident in this rather bleak month .
 Transferring is a good topic of conversation which not only brings sympathy but is a kind of pat on the back that the problem is outside of ourselves . Transferring brings sympathy and is a sort of a good idea that the problems are outside of us .
 Transferring reaches epidemic proportions during January and February when whole groups of friends decide on a mass exit . Transferring takes place during the winter months when friends decide to leave .
 A student gets ready to transfer only to find that he may not be able to do so as easily as he thought . Thus, a student may not have been able to transfer .

 The feeling seems to be that students bring their personal problems with them wherever they go . Students bring personal problems everywhere they go, students say . Students say they bring their problems wherever they are .

 Although all of these students will not transfer, this kind of cry for freedom and responsibility can be heard among them . This kind of universal cry for free and responsibility is heard among these students, says CNN.com .

 Robert Chute spoke to a chapel audience recently, his topic was atheism . He spoke to the chapel audience about atheism .

 Chute failed to provide an adequate basis for ethics and morality, which according to him is basic to any religion, he says . Chute says he is disappointed by the lack of a basis for ethical and moral values .
 Chute would look to the individual as the basis for morality and ethics, he says . Chute: "I'm looking at the individual, not the government, as a model for morality"
 He stated that in a given situation, the decision for right and wrong depends on the individual . He said in the case, the individual is responsible for his actions .
 In allowing each decision to be made in view of the relative circumstances of different situations, Dr. John Sutter says . Dr. Sutter: "In order to make the right decision, each decision must be taken in a very different way"
 In order that decisions about behavior and possible action will not be relative to every situation, men seek ethical assurance . Men seek ethical assurances in order to make sure their behavior is not relative to each situation .
 Ethics is an attempt to formulate and organize principles as a guide for what ought to be done . Ethics is a form of formative principles that should guide what should be done. Ethics is the result of an effort to organize principles that can guide people to the right .
 These principles are not relative, but are applied to specific circumstances for guidance . These principles were not relative but applied for specific circumstances in the U.S.
 The ethical individual does not consider merely the uniqueness of each decision, but instead looks instead to the similarities in different circumstances . "Ethically, the ethical individual is not satisfied with the uniqueness in each decision," he says .
 The ethical-minded concludes that it is not the uniqueness, but the pervasive aspects of human existence that are striking . It is not unique, it is the pervasive aspect of human life that is striking, says the author .
 Chute's belief that atheism is ""more than a denial; it can be an affirmation,"" was not realized in his address . Chute: Atheism is "more than denial" than it is a denial .
 The implications do not ""lead to a satisfactory ethical code,"" but provide the basis for a denial of ethical considerations . The implications don't lead to a "satisfactory ethical code" The implications "do not lead to an ethical code, they say .

 "The last statement to be criticized here is the absurd request to demand that communism be withdrawn from Cuba," he said .
 Most that could be done conceivably would be to force a withdrawal of a number of prominent Communists, or to destory the structure of the Cuban government . The most that could do is to force the withdrawal of some prominent Communists .
 How one can destroy the idea for which the word communism stands is far from being clear . But how one can destroyed the idea of communism is not clear, he says .

 The person whose name appear with a particular statement accept total responsibility for that statement . The person who appears with a certain statement accepts total responsibility . For more information, visit CNN.com/Heroes .
 It should be evident that in a Republican Club which must necessarily include in its membership different strata of political outlook that such an opinion as that to which I refer in this paper could not be construed as representative of the entire group .
 If an article which is of less controversial nature, embodying the sentiment of the whole group, is submitted, it will either go unsigned (as a regular news item) or will bear the name of Public Relations Director, Allen Kerr .

 Robert Lanz Chosen As Business Mgr. at Bates College, Maine, March 6, 1963 . Lanz chosen as business manager at Bates University .
 Robert Lanz '65 will succeed Stephen Barron '64 as business manager of the STUDENT, the Publishing Association announced Wednesday . Lanz "65" succeeds Stephen Barron "64" Barron .
 An economics major from Rockville, Conn., Lanz held the post of STUDENT advertising manager this year . He has been a staff member since his freshman year .
 In addition to his newspaper work, he is a member of the varsity basketball and baseball teams . He was the soccer team's leading scorer this fall . He also plays basketball, baseball and soccer .

 The following Guest Editorial emphasizes the policy of this newspaper, and also provides an example of a student taking advantage of the opportunity the STUDENT affords for expressing opinion .
 The Bates STUDENT is a weekly paper that contains articles in various fields . Guest Editorial is a guest editorial .
 Some of the articles are merely informative, but others are sometimes provocative . Some of these articles are simply informative . Others are provocative .
 These articles are not meant to be read and then thrown away with a shrug of complacency and a ""So What"" attitude . These articles were not intended to be thrown away . Instead, they are meant to have a 'So What' attitude .
 Students who read this newspaper are not concerned about what they read . From the very few, if any, letters received by the Editor of the STUDENT, it would not be unfair to say that .
 Every student knows that this weekly newspaper belongs to the studentry of Bates College . This weekly newspaper is published by Bates College students at the school .
 It would not be harsh to say that very few take advantage of this medium . It would be not be fair to say many people would be interested in using the medium .
 Students prefer to complain about things they do not like to other students . Instead of complaining, students prefer to talk about things with other students, they complain .
 The STUDENT is not only read by the student body of Bates College, but by subscribers and alumni, alumni, trustees of Bates, and parents of students . It is also read by subscribers, alumni and alumni .
 This weekly newspaper is the best medium to let others know about your grievances, opinions, and attitudes on different topics of campus as well as universal interest . Surely this week newspaper is best medium for people to vent their grievances .

 In reply to the article appearing in last week's ""Sporting Scene"" regarding the validity of the use of the fiber-glass pole, I would like to present the opposing side of the argument .
 Charles Dvorak vaulted 11 ' 6"" with a plain, old-fashioned hickory pole in 1904 . In 1904 an Olympic champion in 1904 he vaulted an Olympic record 11 " 6" with a simple old fashioned pole .
 Dvorak remembers a similar controversy upon the introduction of the bamboo pole . According to his statement in Life Magazine, the bamboo poles were introduced in 1972 .
 Cornelius Warmerdam, using a bamboo pole, soared over 15' consistently . He soared from 15' to 15' using bamboo pole .
 The greatest fault with the bamboo pole is the danger of its breaking while in a bent position . The bamboo pole can also be broken in bent position, experts say .
 A high-school vaulter in Bristol, Conn., was vaulting with bamboo when the pole snapped below his hands and fatally speared him . The pole was vaulted with bamboo .
 Following this, the bamboo pole was outlawed — because of its danger only . The bamboo pole is now banned in Japan .
 Don ""Tarzen"" Bragg held the record of 15' 9 l 4"" with an aluminum pole until fiber-glass pole was introduced . Bragg set the record with a 15'9 l 4" pole . Don Bragg was the world record holder .
 In his opinion, pole vaulting is merely going through an evolutionary pattern all over again . In my opinion, poles vaulting has evolved through evolutionary patterns, he says .
 The switch from metal to fiber-glass is comparable to the switch from the hickory pole to bamboo . The switch is similar to a switch from a metal pole to a bamboo pole, experts say .
 The February 23rd issue of Sports Illustrated states that today's science is capable of developing a metal pole which will surpass fiber-glass in flexibility . The pole will be able to be flexible enough to withstand bending bending and bending .
 Budd Held developed a new, more streamlined javelin which would go much farther than the type formerly in use . Held developed the new type which could go much further than the old type .
 There was no fuss about its entry into the sport, although it radically revised records . This was introduced into track and field and there were no fuss with its entry .
 Formerly, hitting a hurdle on the way over was like hitting a stone wall . Formerly it was like 'hitting a hurdle' was 'like hitting a wall' Formerly the hurdle was 'hit by a hurdle', but now it's a hurdle .
 Today's hurdles have been streamlined, both in style and in the introduction of aluminum as the basic material, allowing it to give upon contact .
 These examples are merely to illustrate that various ""evolutionary changes"" are, in actuality, very common and normal occurrances . These examples were merely to . illustrate that evolutionary changes are very common .
 The vault is sup posed to have a foreign implement incorporated in its tech nique . The vault was built in the 1980s .
 Unlike the pole vault, the high jump is an event requiring only an individual and a bar . Unlike pole vaulting, the event requires only a single individual and bar .
 The introduction of this outside help in the form of a special shoe defeats the original purpose of an athlete using his own ability to clear the bar .
 The introduction of the fiber glass pole has definitely in creased the spectator interest in the pole vault . The introduction has creased interest in pole vaulting .
 Although they paid for various services, they were not allowed to decide how the money they supplied was to be spent . Basically, although they paid . for various . services, the . money they . supplied was not . decided how they were to spend .
 As part of our bills, we pay for the activities of certain campus organizations such as the Student Council, Student Government, and the Christian Association . We pay for these activities as part of the bills .
 According to the Extra-Curricular Activities Committee, the funds of these organizations are alloted according to the decisions of the committee alone . The funds will be alloted by the committee .
 The committee voted February 26 to forbid the proposed transfer of funds to the junior class . The committee votes February 26 .
 One of the two student members of the committee joined the majority in rejecting the proposal .
 It is the administration that feels uneasy about getting involved in subsidies . The administration is wary of getting involved with subsidies .
 The group has but two members . It seems to be dedicated to providing a "broad base for democratic" education .
 The Extracurricular Activities Committee, it seems, has the unchallenged right to control, in whatever way it wishes, the expenditures of organizations run by the students . Students run the organizations with money supplied by students, the committee says .
 The offensive team must attempt to make a basket within 24 seconds of their possession of the ball . Now the offensive team has to attempt to score a basket in the last 24 seconds .

 Countryman's attack is aimed at what has come to be called the ""Negro ghetto"" so prominent in many of our Eastern states' largest cities . Countryman: "I'm sorry for what has become known as the 'negro ghetto'
 The problem is acute and will alter the future of the country""s cities," says the government . "The problem is severe and will change the future," says President Vladimir Putin .
 "He comes seeking a degree of personal freedom and finds instead the enigma of helplessness," he says . He comes seeking freedom but finds instead of finding it in a "enigma"
 A job (a sort of serfdom to the elevator and the janitor's mop), a home (three rooms in a firetrap), and here he remains. A job, a home, a job, and a home .
 Business in its purest form has become mass production at the lowest possible cost . "Mass production" is mass production, mass production in the way of mass production .
 Those jobs ""traditionally"" held by Negros, no longer require a human being. Negros are no longer employed in the Philippines . Negros no longer need to be employed in order to survive .
 "All around him the Negro sees the status symbols of a life that has no place for him," says the author . The Negro lives in a life of status symbols that have no place in his life, he says .
 In the ghetto, isolation replaces gregariousness. Eventually, he withdraws from his own community in the ghetto . "Imitigating" is a form of isolation .
 Political concerns cease to be important to him mainly because they, in fact, don't concern him and never have . Political concerns stop being important because they are not important enough to him .
 "The black man adopts this spirit as an alternative to what is offered by the white man's world," says the author . The black man's spirit is "an alternative to the white world"
 Such unrest is prevalent today among the masses of of of lower class Negros . Such unrest was prevalent in the Negros in the 1960s .
 Countryman pointed out that organization within the Negro community itself can mobilize the collective efforts of well over One million Negros in this country . Countryman said organization within Negro community can mobilize collective efforts .
 Unless conditions in the Negro's immediate environment are changed drastically, this force can become a formidable form of violent expression . The Negro is a powerful force that can only be found in the immediate environment .
 First, by making the North as aware of the imminent dangers of allowing this persistent degradation of the Negro, and secondly, by giving the Negro a fresh look at himself . The North should be aware of this imminent danger, says the author .
 The individual must have a sense of belonging to a society, of being a participant . The latter is the more important, for the individual to be a member of a society .
 The Negro must be acutely aware of the political and social mechanism available to him for improving his lot . The Negro is aware of what is available for him to improve his lot, he says .
 "He must learn to fight that which he presently cannot understand," he says . He must also fight a system of institutionalized prejudice, he writes .

 The Student Senate Constitution is now well on its way to becoming a reality for Bates students . If* TWO BATES STUDENT, MARCH 13, 1963 Senate Constitution Passes Extra-Curric Committee .
 Women's Student Government and men's Student Council would be incorporated under the general heading of Student Senate . Under this system of government, the now separate women's Student . government would be merged into the General heading of Senate .
 The composition of the women's Proctor Council would remain the same, but the men's government would be revised to the same form . Men's Proctors Council would have the same composition as women's government .
 The proposed constitution passed a preliminary vote of the student body last Spring . Last Spring, the proposed constitution was approved by the student population .
 This fall, the committee made minor revisions, and sent the completed constitution to the Extra-Curricular Activities Committee . The committee has made minor changes to the constitution .
 ExtraCurric passed the Senate Constitution two weeks ago . The Extra-Curricular Activities Committee vetoed plans for the Ivy Day Dance .
 The committee has resolved that any class dance must provide a budget based solely on anticipated ticket sales . The committee also resolved that the committee has a budget for the event .

 The pair didn't waste time discussing the pros and cons of the venture . Nor did they waste a single minute discussing the merits and merits of the new venture .

 The finale was an all out effort on the huge double door on the south end of the edifice . It was a huge effort to complete the project .
 Pail after pail of water was thrown on to freeze the soggy snow . Water arrived by the ashcanful aboard toboggans hastily rigged for the job .

 A brief analysis of the Bates electoral process appeared in the previous issue of the STUDENT . STate 2 3771 FOUR BATES STUDENT, APRIL 3, 1963 Editorials .
 It leads to an informed electorate and subsequently to the increased effectiveness of a campus organization . Also, it leads to a better understanding of the electorate and the effectiveness of the campus organization.
 Students would like to know what the organization's function is, and who its members are, would be better known by students .
 The electoral process should be structured to allow, in every instance, for an informed electorate, and where possible, for active campaign. The electoral system should be designed to allow the electorate to be informed and engaged in an active campaign, says David Cameron .
 Dan Ustick '63, this year's past chairman of the Student Council's elections committee, points out that during the special freshman election in the fall, interest and enthusiasm was noteworthy . Ustick: "Interest and enthusiasm" was noteworthy during the election .
 With more time, ""parties"" or groups of candidates and supporters would have gotten together and campaigned for office . Indeed, with more time,. parties would have been able to get together and campaign for office.
 In this initial election, male and female members of a class vote not only for their officers, but also for their representatives to the Student Council and Government, respectively . In this election, students will be able to elect representatives to their Student Council, Government .
 It is this electoral system that should be maintained for subsequent elections . The electoral system should be kept in place for future elections . It is a good example of the electoral system being maintained .
 Instead of all the men electing the Student Council, the representatives from each class should be elected by only the men of each class . The Student Council should only be made up of men in each class, not all of the men .
 All that the Student Senate Constitution provides, in effect, is that the present Student Council and Student Government, can meet together . All that is required is that they meet together, the Constitution provides .
 In the selection of officers, all the men would continue to elect the male members, and all the women, the female members of the Senate . The Senate would also elect the men and women who would be selected as officers .
 Without increased campaigning, the present extent of uninformed voting or non-voting, among the men at least, would continue . And without increased campaigning it would continue to be a problem .
 To have the system used in freshman elections continued for all four years would result in better elections . The system should be continued for the next four years, according to the author .
 Senate office-seeker must consider 90^125 students . Each of these voters would become significant .
 If an office-seeker is not known by some of his constituents, he would have to make himself known . If he was not known, he'd have to .
 With a relatively small constituency, the task would be neither difficult nor avoidable . The task would not be difficult or avoidable, but it would be both avoidable.
 With only one hundred or so votes cast in his particular race, every vote is that much more decisive . With only 100 votes to cast in a race, there are only a few hundred votes to be cast .
 Perhaps this structural change cannot overcome the ""passivity"", or whatever you wish to call it, that characterizes Bates College . Bates College has a reputation for being 'passivity'
 If some remnant of the enthusiasm that characterizes freshman, and their elections, does survive, it should be maintained rather than consumed by the electoral process . But if some of it survives, the enthusiasm should be kept alive .

 Paul Goodman's new book The Community of Scholars is published by Paul Goodman . Goodman's thesis is that the community of scholars is at risk of over-academic error .
 The original function of a college was to bring students and men of learning together in a community where the students wanted to learn and the scholars wanted to teach, says Goodman .
 The American colleges and universities have become adjuncts of the larger world . They are not run by their faculties and students, but by their administrations under pressure from trustees and legislators, says Julian Zelizer .
 The students waste time 1 and the role of the faculty is compromised by Administration and its own academism . The role of faculty should be compromised by the Administration and the faculty, says the author .
 Finally, colleges lose their function; which is ideally to refresh the larger community by insisting on higher' purposes and rediscovering new meanings within human experience .
