 Garnet baseball team returned last week from a successful swing into the South where they officially opened their season with a record of 1-1 .
 The Bobcat Pastimers beat Washington College by the score of 9-1 . They also dropped a 10th inning clash to highly-rated Rider 2-1 in the final game .
 This trip, the first such excursion in four years, evidenced the presence of some prime quality pitching in both the Garnet and opposing teams . This trip was the first of four years .
 The weather was much colder than expected, proving to hamper somewhat the potential of Bates hitters . The weather hamper some of their potential .
 The teams got some fine work in and the trip in general was regarded as a success . Despite this obstacle, however, the teams were able to enjoy the trip .
 The 'Cats beat Washington College 1-0 in their opening game . The game was played at the home of Washington College in Maryland .
 Ted Krzynowek started for the Bobcats, pitched four innings of no-hit ball, struck out 9 opponents, and received credit for the win . The Bobcats won the game 4-2 .
 Ted Beal in the 5th inning and Bob Lanz in the 8th inning struck out the side of the side . He was followed by Ted Beal and Ted Lanz in 5th and 8th innings .
 The 'Cats were held to one hit, a triple from the bat of Archy Lanza by Washington's ace, Chuck Meding . They teed off on the next two pitchers, with the next three being hit .
 John Yuskis, playing his first varsity baseball game, got 2 hits, and along with Bill Davis played a very important part in Bates' big first inning . Bill Davis also played an important part .
 Davis went on to get on base four times and score four times . Davis scored four times in the first inning . Davis also scored four runs in the game .
 The Bates bats gradually demolished the efforts of both the second and third pitchers . Red Vandersea hit a two-run homer to put the game beyond reach in the 5th .
 Also of importance was the fine base running displayed by Bill Davis, Ron Taylor and John Lanza . Bill Davis and Ron Taylor ran the base running .
 Thorn Freeman can expect some good support from Ted Krzynowek and Bob Lanzell . Now Thorn Freeman will be able to speak to the public for the first time .

 Delaware was one of the better teams Bates has played in the past few years and they certainly proved it through their talent displayed . Delaware was the better team Bates has seen in recent years .
 Bates' only run came in the 2nd when Ronnie Taylor walked, stole second, and scored on Fred Woolson's sharp line drive to right . The game ended in a 1-1 victory for the Bates team .
 The Blue Hens scored two more runs in the first inning . After that, the 'Cats' hitting turned as cold as the weather .
 On the final day of the trip, the team traveled to Trenton, New Jersey, to play Rider College . The team lost in the 10th place on the trip .
 In the last of the 10th inning the score was tied 1 to 1 with Rider at bat . Rider was at the top of the score in the game .

 Seven Bates Graduate heads Baseball . William J Leahey, better known to the Bates students as ""Chick"", has been an omnipresent figure on the Maine sports scene .
 He was captain and quarterback of the 1942 Maine Championship football team . He also played quarterback for the Maine Championship Football team .
 Leahey entered the Marine Air Corps in 1943 and served 43 months — 15 of which were spent overseas . He served in the Air Force for 43 months .
 He batted .310 and made a fine double-play combination with Jerry Snyder . Snyder played for the Washington Senators .
 The next year he was a teammate of the Yankee great Whitey Ford at Norfolk (Class B) where he batted .275 . The next season he was teammates of the Yankees legend Whitey . Ford .
 Leahey decided to forsake pro-ball, returned to Lewiston and entered Bates . He has never regretted his decision to enter Bates College in Maine .
 Because he had played pro-* baseball he was ineligible for college sports but still coached freshman baseball and basketball his last three years . Because of that, he is ineligible to participate in college sports .
 He continued playing baseball with the Auburn Aces, a local semi-pro team for several seasons .
 Leahey earned a master's degree from Columbia a year later . Holds a Masters degree .
 Leahey returned to his alma-mater as the baseball coach and v. basketball mentor . One and a half years later he returned to the school as a baseball coach .
 Coach Leahey considers Bob Dunn the best allaround player he's ever had . Dunn is considered one of the best players he has ever played with . Dunn was a star player in the 1980s .
 College's Proving Ground Coach Leahey feels that the colleges are becoming more and more the proving ground for major league ball players . Coach says colleges are proving or testing grounds for big league players . College's proving ground coach says colleges have become more popular with players .
 Minor league baseball has suffered a decline in recent years due to television . Minor league teams have been unable to compete in major league baseball because of TV .
 Small college baseball has been weakened because of the cutting down of summer baseball leagues which gave college stars necessary experience . Summer leagues gave college players necessary experience.
 All-star list includes all-stars from Bob Dunn, Bob Atwater, Joe Murphy, Norm Clarke, Ralph Davis, Albert DeSantis, Bob Martin, Wayne Cain, Bob Reny, Norm Clark and Jerry Feld .

 Each dorm will have a place to leave books, with Page Hall serving as the central parking place . This drive will help provide the educational materials needed in those areas where voter registration projects are taking place .
 The conditions which the book drive is designed — hopefully — to alleviate are desperate . The conditions are desperate, but the conditions which are desperate are desperate.
 The Negro colleges to whom these books will be going have virtually non-existent libraries, and it's almost impossible for the students to get good books . The books are going to be going to Negro colleges where they are going .
 In the places where voter registration projects are taking place, the books will be used to teach the people to read .
 The voter registration exams are usually quite difficult, and an attempt to prepare the prospective voter is a vital part of the program . The exams are often quite difficult and difficult to prepare .
 Churches in the LewistonAuburn area are taking part in this drive . The churches in the area are supporting the drive .
 Other church groups, as a result of students speaking to their ministers during spring vacation, will also run drives .
 In addition, this project is and has been taking place on college campuses throughout the country .
 This project, as well as the speakers on campus concerning civil rights, is an effort to involve more students in this is sue. This project is a project to involve students in the civil rights movement. The project is part of a larger effort at the University of Columbia .

 Dean Boyce Outlines Off-Campus Policy to maintain the Bates tradition of being a centralized residential college . President and Trustees have decided to eliminate off-campus residence .
 Off-campus living began only recently in 1956 with the closing of naval ""quantum" houses, which created a large surplus of students without quarters . The closing of the naval ""Quantum"" houses in 1956 created a huge surplus of quarters .
 The college hopes to include all men within campus houses . The proposed men's dorm near Smith, and new rooms in Roger Williams Hall with a smaller men's enrollment .
 Married or commuting students, or those living with faculty will not be included in the list .
 By the senior year of the \ Class of '65, this goal will be nearly realized . The goal is to be realized by the seniors of the Class '65 .
 The size of the incoming class will, at that time, have been reduced for two years in a row .
 Sophomores who would like to room off-campus during their senior year, will be allowed to do so only if they are successful in obtaining off campus residence for their junior year, too . Students will be able to stay in residence off campus for their senior years if successful .

 A recent editorial in The Bridgeport Post said of ""home"" ""That home is ... 'a heap of liv ing' beyond price. That home is a heap of living ing" beyond price .
 The home represents a loyalty among those who dwell therein, that goes deep reaches far, and outlasts the years . The home is a loyalty that goes beyond the years, and outlasting the years.
 "To brace it against every strain, guard it from every dan ger — particularly the danger o:' uncaring — that it our task. To brace it ... that it's our task," he says .

 At a recent tutorial meeting, reflections and problems encountered during tutoring were discussed . Lewiston By PAM YOUNG '65 .
 Lewiston High teachers have been reassuring at the start of the school year . Some tutors were discouraged, but the warm friendliness of the teachers has been reassuring .
 This tutorial meeting brought out a discussion and exchange of approaches used by the tutors . The tutorial meeting took place last Thursday, which brought out discussion .
 Many tutors were impressed with the gravity of the situation, and the difficulty which many of us encounter when we try to understand why a senior in high school doesn't know the difference .
 Many students find the biggest problem they have to cope with is that of very poorly motivated students . Interest High is interest high for students .
 Many tutors have found themselves trying to project their own attitudes and ambitions on the Lewiston students . Lewiston is a small town in Washington state .
 When a student is not personally ambitious, some tutors find that they feel disappointed . Some tutors feel disappointed with the student's lack of personal ambition .
 It has been hard to realize that most of the students we work with are just interested in getting through a course . It's hard to think that most students are interested in just getting through the course .
 The interest on both the part of the tutor and the tutee is very high . Nevertheless, the interest is still high, says the tutor .
 One tutor brought an issue of the Garnet to a session and had her students grapple with some of the poems . The Garnet is a collection of poetry from the 18th century .
 Others have tried to provide interest by referring as often as possible to sports . Others have used to refer to sports as a matter of interest .
 Some tutors have found themselves reading the Lewiston paper so as not to be behind on what's happening in Lewiston High basketball .
 Because this program is still very new, there are a great many problems which will have to be straightened out, says CNN.com.com's John Sutter .
 To help the tutors, a list of books to which they can refer is in the process of being compiled .
 In addition to discussions with the high school guidance department, an attempt is being made to provide more homogeneous grouping for the tutors .
 Slowly, the tutorial is evolving into a smoothly-working and definitely satisfying program . The tutorial is now a smoothly working program .

 He stressed the importance of the Youth Employment Act of 1963, introduced in the Senate by Sen. Sen. Richard Hatch .
 This bill would establish a Youth Conservation Corps (patterned after the successful New Deal agency, the Civilian Conservation Corps) and a local employment program . It would involve activity of young people in state and local government and private, non-profit organizations .
 The proposals are a follow-up to the youth employment provisions for occupational training, passed in the Manpower Development and Training Act of last year .
 The Youth Conservation Corps is also expected to reduce the eight billion dollar backlog for conservation projects in national and state parks and forests . The Corps will also reduce the backlog of conservation projects .
 The Local Area Youth Employment Program should provide service for public and private local agencies whose funds are limited . The program should be used by agencies that have limited funds to employ youth .
 This Act, it is hoped, will reduce delinquency when young people with no satisfactory prospects are able to find work . It is hoped that this will reduce delinquent behaviour .
 At present, unemployed youths between 16 and 21 comprise only 7% of the potential labor force, but 18% of total unemployed . Unemployed youths between the ages of 16-21 comprise only seven% of potential workforce .
 By 1965, the labor force will have to absorb 3. million young people, a nearly 50% increase over the 1960 figure of 2. million . Service in the YCC is limited to men .
 The pay ranges from $60 per month for the first six-month enrollment to $65 per month . Total service may not exceed two years . The pay is between $60 and $65 a month .
 In addition to the above benefits, the enrollee re ceives tax-free room, board, transportation, and health and recreational facilities .
 The Local Area Youth Educa tion Program is open to men and women who would be employed by state and local agencies . The program is available in the local area for men and woman working in the program .
 They would work in schools, hospi tals, settlement houses, parks, parks and libraries . Visiting Nurses Associa tions, orphanages, and the like .
 Major condition for their employment is that no regular worker be displaced . Naturally, a major condition for them is that they are not displaced by regular workers .
 Each service is to be headed by its own Director under the authority of the Secretary of Labor . Each service will have its own director under authority from the secretary of labor .
 Appropriations would be determined by Congress according to annual necessity . Appro priations would then be determined according to Congress .
 Youngs Dems Urge Support The Young Democratic Clubs of America are enthusiastically endorsing this proposed bill . The bill would be the first time a bill has been passed in the Senate .
 As Medicare concerns the aged, so does the Youth Employment Act concern us, our contemporaries, and our communities . The act is important for the future of the country and its communities .
 A Congressman cannot judge public opinion if no opinion is ex-pressed . Mere rec ognition of the problem as one of direct concern and passive, is not enough .

 Dr. Loomer Outlines Relation Of Religion To Colleges . Dr. Bates College, LEWISTON, MAINE, was a major college in Maine .
 Loomer, a Bates graduate, is a member of the American Theological Society, an Honorary Fellow in the National Council of Religion in Higher Education, and a . member of . the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People . People of African American descent .

 Loomer was selected for the Sports Illustrated Silver Anniversary All-American football team . He played for the University of Washington in Washington State in 1964 .

 My last criticism concerns the ideal nature of a college such as Bates is ideal . Bates College is a college with a purpose of purpose .
 This ideal function is to bring students and men of learning together in a community where the students wish to learn and the scholars want to teach . The ideal function of the school is to be a community of learning, not just students .
 It should always exist for the sake of knowledge and never for the production of marketable skills . It should never be for profit, it should be for knowledge, not for marketability skills .
 The administration should always be subservient to the faculty and students in realizing this ideal . The university should always strive to achieve the ideal of subservience to students .

 The Bates Bobcats made a rousing start last week to the northern part of their 1963 baseball schedule with two impressive victories over Massachusetts teams .
 On Thursday at Medford, Bates clipped Tufts 3-0, and followed up this win with an 11-5 pounding of American International on Friday at Springfield . Bates also beat American International 11-4 on Friday .
 Pitching, hitting, and fielding were more than adequate in both games, and occasionally bordered on the spectacular .
 The outlook continues to be very bright, and less than a week remains before the home season opens next Monday with Lowell Tech at Garcelon Field . M.I.T. will play in Cambridge on Saturday .
 Thorn Freeman stopped the Jumbos cold with a four-hit shutout against Tufts .
 The game started off as a pitchers' duel between Freeman and Jumbo hurler Wally Wadman . Bates sent only seven batters up in the first two innings of the game .
 Paul Holt opened the third with a walk, and Freeman's drag bunt single put two men on . Freeman also scored a run of two runs for Holt .

 Freeman scored two runs in the first half of the game . He was also helped out by two double plays started by Holt at shortstop .
 Ron Taylor socked one of Wadman's offerings for a tremendous home run to left in the seventh inning to ice the Bobcat victory .

 Freeman had another single to go with his bunt . Other hits were made by Bill Davis, Bud Spector, and Bud Holt .

 The rebuilding of the roof of Smith Hall will be undertaken during the coming summer . Dr. Aikman '65, Secretary -Treasurer Smith To Be Renovated This Summer .
 The current flat roof will be replaced with a pitched roof similar to that on the other college buildings . As part of the rebuilding project the parapet surrounding the present roof will also be removed .
 It is expected that the new roof will permit improved drainage and snow removal as well as minimize maintenance problems . The new roof is expected to be used to reduce maintenance problems in the city .
 Design of the structure has been the work of the college architect, Alonzo J Harriman and Associates of Auburn . The contract has been awarded to the Paul B McClellan Co., Inc., of Portland .

 Bates College is celebrating its one hundredth birthday in the 1963-1964 college year . The doors of Hathorn Hall opened for the first class of Maine State Seminary on September 1, 1857 . Bates College has existed continuously as an educational institution since 1857.
 The Seminary, ""a school of high order or grade somewhere between a College and an Academy,"" had been conceived by a Free-Will Baptist minister and one-time teacher .
 Its material resources when classes started consisted of the newly completed Hathorn Hall, an unfinished dormitory, Parker Hall, and twenty acres of land donated by the Franklin Company of Boston .
 Citizens of Lewiston and Auburn had given $15,000 to start the school . State legislature had granted $5,000 in cash and $10,000 for script to start school .
 Whether President Cheney had originally intended that Maine State Seminary should become a college no one really knows . Cheney's original intent was to create a college, but no one knows why .
 There is evidence that this was his goal, but that he decided to promote the new venture as a seminary . There would have been a great deal of opposition to a new college, since Bowdoin and Colby already existed . Many of the Free Will Baptists felt that higher
 The college was named for Benjamin E Bates, a Boston businessman who had a substantial interest in the local textile mills . The college is named for the businessman who owned a large stake in local textile milles .
 Maria Wheelwright Mitchell was the first woman to receive a diploma from the college in 1869 . The college was co-educational from the beginning .
 Charter Day will be celebrated with a community testimonial dinner on January 18 next year . In view of the assistance that local people gave to get the college started, it is appropriate that Charter Day should be celebrated .
 Tradewinds play a variety of instruments, including guitars, banjoes, mandolins, conga and bonga drums . They also play conga drums, banjo, mandolin, guitars and banjo drums .
 There are 4,000 Peace Corps opportunities in forty-four countries . The Peace Corps is based in the United States and Canada . There are more than 4,500 opportunities in the Peace Corps .
 Children's Cancer Research Foundation in Boston has two positions open for full-time, permanent chemical research assistants . Chemical research assistants are needed for children's cancer research .
 The research program is mainly involved with the synthesis of new organic substances as potential anti-cancer agents . The program is based on synthesis of organic substances that could be used to develop new cancer treatments .
 The laboratories are located in the Jimmy Fund Building adjoining Children's Hospital and the Harvard Medical School . The Jimmy Fund building is located adjacent to Children's hospital and Harvard Medical school .

 Three Passion And Intensity Prevent Hamlet From Taking Action . Hamlet is being shipped off to England by the king whom he wants to kill in revenge .
 Hamlet's inability to consummate his revenge appears to be the concern of the play . The response to this question is the question Hamlet is to answer .
 The most elucidating approach to the play, therefore, seems to lie in an understanding of Hamlet's problem . Hamlet is not the only problem Hamlet faces, but it is a problem .
 In the course of the play we are given those elements of Hamlet's personality and temperament most important in explaining his actions . Attempt To Understand Hamlet: Hamlet is Hamlet .
 He has the passion and intensity of students and youth, though they are directed more to a student's idealism than to the action of, say, a Claudius . He has a passion for idealism, but it's more to the idealism of a student than to a Claud
 This is illustrated in his attempt to understand and do the right thing, to act in the light of truth . This was illustrated by his attempts to understand the truth and act in light of it .
 The death of his father shocked him, but his state was intensified with the almost immediate remarriage of his mother . His mother remarried him almost immediately after the death .
 A distraught son's mind could easily construe something rotten in this state of affairs . The son's father is a father of a son of a woman who has been married for more than 20 years .
 With the entrance of the ghost, therefore, suspicions of foul play are validated . The so-far dormant suspicions have been validated by the ghost .
 He thereby gives his vengeance the second thought which changes the emotion into a more intellectual consideration, retribution, retribution . The author of the novel "Revengevenge" is not satisfied with the idea of retribution .
 The author's concern with the problem before him reaches philosophic proportions . The novel is about an idealistic student who is concerned with the problems before him .
 The spirit I have seen T' assume a pleasing shape, yea, and perhaps Out of my weakness and my melancholy, As he is very potent with such spirits, Abuses me to damn me. As he was very potent .
 If his occulted guilt Do not itself unkennel in one speech It is a damned ghost that we have seen And my imaginations are foul As Vulcan's stithy. And my imagination is foul. If he is guilty, he is not guilty of murder, he's
 The development of the vengeance motif from emotion to intellect causes Hamlet's initial doubt that the king is guilty . Hamlet begins Hamlet in the playwright's version of the play .
 The problem that accompanies this is his inability to act in the face of his belief in the truth of the king's guilt . The problem is that he is not able to act because he believes in his belief .

 Hamlet speaks to the Norwegian captain and learns that men are going to fight even against ridiculous odds . Hamlet's inability to act foiled yet more painfully in the instance of the players, their concern for the fate of persons not even connected with them .
 He sails for England and one cannot forsee that he'll ever take his revenge, except when pushed to a point at which he can only act impulsively . One can't predict that he will ever take revenge, only when pushed for it .
 In the final scene this happens to him. and it seems almost an accident that the king dies . It certainly doesn't seem the result of a wellplanned scheme .
 Six people were killed in the death of the one murderer, instead of one, in the shooting . The suspect was found guilty of shooting six people in the head, police say .
 Throughout the play Hamlet is restrained from action by his own contemplative mind . Tragedy throughout the play is Hamlet's attempt to save his life .
 As a student he is more dominated by the intellectual considerations of his action than by the simple impetuous fulfillment of revenge, as Laertes is, in contrast . The writer is dominated by intellectual considerations as a student .
 Hamlet, by virtue of his temperament, is unable to act, and thus the tragedy, not only of Hamlet . Hamlet's temperament is the reason for the tragedy of the state of Denmark .
 Each night brings with it A cool east breeze To heap the darkness Around my house, In my field And on my trees .

 The amendments were framed and sent to the Extra-Curricular Committee, which was to decide on the merit of the proposed change . After two meetings and considerable discussion, the amendments have been framed .

 Board voted unanimously in support of these amendments and recommended that ExtraCurric follow suit . Board voted in favor of the amendments, recommending that the school board follow suit. Board also voted unanimously for the amendment .
 If the business and editorial aspects are to be kept separate, it makes little difference that their terms of office are the same . If the matter is to be separated, it will not be a big difference in terms of terms .
 That these amendments are essential to the efficient functioning of the STUDENT is obvious to those involved with this newspaper . The amendments are important to the efficiency of this newspaper.
 Extra-Curric Committee vetoed the second and more important amendment . Committee also vetoed the other amendment to the bill .
 The business and editorial staffs are to be separate entities, and in instances of conflict or decision, the P A. will act .
 The P A. thirteen member Board cannot function in this manner . It is a weekly newspaper, and therefore demands that instances which involve both business and editorial decisions be resolved quickly .
 Mirror, which is published but once a year, does not have this bifurcation of responsibility . The Mirror, published but published only once, has responsibility for publishing .
 The P A. wished to have the two publications on the same basis, was another reason for amending the constitution . The constitution was amended in 2007 to allow the publication of two publications .
 The notion that the Publishing Association can be ""ultimately responsible"" for this newspaper is fallacious on two counts . The Publishing Association is not responsible for the newspaper's success .
 It is the Editor who, in practice, must assume such responsibility, but is restrained by the absence of constitutional sanction . Secondly, it is the editor who, as a result, must take responsibility for such a decision .

 Margery Zimmerman '64 paper, all relevant comments are considered and welcome . All relevant comments about the paper are welcome .
 The subject of most of the derogatory conversation on this campus is the Monday and Friday Chapel Assembly Program . The program is a weekly chapel assembly program . The Chapel Assembly program is the subject of the most derogatory conversation .
 The purpose of the program is to inform students about various subjects and events which would not ordinarily be covered in their regular classes . The program is aimed at students who are interested in various subjects not covered in regular classes.
 This purpose is basically good, but it is not being accomplished under the present system . This purpose, however, is being achieved under the current system, he says .
 There are two problems which must be overcome in order for Chapel Assemblies to be worthwhile . Chapel assemblies must be held in order to make them worthwhile, says Bishop .
 Only about one in every three or four programs is effective, or says something worthwhile, says CNN.com.com's John Sutter .
 For one thing, students tend to react against anything that is compulsory . For another thing, they react against the idea of compulsory education .
 Students are forced to hear two or three poor programs for each good one . Students are not even able to get anything out of the one good program, says CNN.com .
 First, reduce the frequency of the assemblies to, for example, once every two weeks . Then reduce the number of assemblies to once a week .
 With fewer and better programs the students will come of their own accord . With fewer programs, fewer programs will help students come of own accord, he says . "With fewer programs," he says, "the students will be better off with fewer programs."
 The result of this change would be the accomplishment of the purpose of Chapel Assembly . Chapel Assembly would be a result of the change .

 The graduate fellowships are available under the Fulbright-Hays Act of 1961 . They are administered by the Institute of International Education as part of the educational exchange program of State .
 United States government full grants, joint U.S.-other government grants; and travel-only grants . United States grants include full grants and joint grants . The grants are part of the United States Government grants .
 Joint awards are available for study in Boliva, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Poland, Poland and Venezuela .
 Travel-only awards are available for study in Austria, Brazil, Denmark, France, Germany, Israel, Italy, Italy and the Netherlands . Travel-Only awards are also available in Austria and Brazil .
 Institute calls special attention to opportunities available in Ceylon, Iceland, Iran, Pakistan, Poland, Rumania, Turkey and the United Arab Republic . Institute calls for opportunities in Iceland, Pakistan and Poland .
 Special opportunities are also available to graduate students interested in teaching English as a foreign language at universities in India, India, Italy and Italy .
 United States citizenship (at the time of application), a bachelor's degree or its equivalent before the beginning date of the grant, language proficiency sufficient to carry out the proposed project and for general communication, and good health .
 A good academic record and demonstrated capacity for independent study are also necessary . A good Academic record is also necessary in order to qualify for the top job .
 Preference given to applicants under 35 years of age who have not previously lived or studied abroad . Preference is given to those under 35 who have previously lived and studied abroad. Applicants must be under 35 .

 Federal aid to Bates College, manifested in the form of Student Loans, is due for a drastic revision by the present session of Congress . College Aid might Decrease next year .
 The present Federal aid program has been an accumulative one in that each year the funds available to colleges across the nation has reached a ceiling in the present school year . Each year, each year, the federal aid program reaches a ceiling .
 The funds made available by the ceiling mentioned above will merely be divided up among the applicants resulting in a decrease all around . Unless corrective measures are taken by the present Congress in the form of a bill now pending before the legislative body, the funds will be reduced .

 Dr. Loomer: "Education should help the individual move towards integrity" Integrity is central to individual's education, he said .
 Loomer defined integrity as a sense of wholeness and unity . Religious leaders are most concerned with four major goals of higher education; integrity, freedom, the academic community, and intellectual .
 "The person of integrity remains the same person, conscious of his unique identity, regardless of circumstances or location," says the author of the book .
 The movement towards integrity entails a constantly increasing ability to think systematically and relationally in awareness of the differences and similarities between areas of experience . The movement to integrity entails an increasing ability .
 Without a systematic coherence between experiences of his life, the thinker becomes fragmented, less than ""one self"" in a related universe . The thinker is less than "one self"
 Integrity also leads to selfconsciousness, knowledge of one's values and purposes, an awareness of intellectual strengths and weaknesses, and a greater trust in one's own reactions .
 In any society based on the democratic ideal, it is the duty of higher education to give rise to individuals who know their values and whose decisions rest on selfconfidence and self-respect .
 The studen^ must realize that every system economic, or political — is based on a small cluster of ideas which are self-supporting, he says .
 This foundation constitutes the individual's integrity and is his perspective on life . The foundation of this person's integrity constitutes his integrity, says CNN.com .
 The unique perspective which he has achieved is but one among many, he says . He must also recognize that there are other integrities, he writes .
 Unable to accept others may be measured by the inability to accept oneself . The inability of accepting others may also be measured in terms of acceptance .
 Education should develop intellectual creativity and should lead to a release from personal weaknesses through awareness of such weaknesses . Education should also lead to an awareness of those weaknesses, author says. Education should help students release themselves from their weaknesses .
 One must be willing to relate ideas and concepts to emotions, recognizing that the ""conceptual feeling"" and the ""emotional feeling"" are interdependent .
 The Westminster Choir of forty voices is the touring concert unit of Westminster College in Princeton, New Jersey . A third point of academic em em em hosts a touring concert .
 The Choir has performed since 1921 and is now one of the best known choral groups in the world . It is now the world's most famous choral group .
 For over 30 years it was conducted by John Finley Williamson . Williamson was the founder of the organisation, which now runs its own website .
 The Choir's present conductor, Warren Martin, is a graduate of the college and former member of the Choir .
 Warren Martin taught theory, composition and conducting . He was Director of Graduate Studies at the University of Cambridge in 1950 .
 He was appointed Musical Director of the college in 1958, and presently holds this position . He has been a member of the College since 1958 .
 As conductor of the Westminster Touring Choir, he has directed the group in numerous performances . He has directed numerous performances for the group .

 John Bart '64, Pamela Ball '64 and Sally O Smyth '65 Editorial Assistant Perry Bruder '65 . Pamela Ball' '64 Editorial Assistant David A Nelson Faculty Advisor .
 I heartily agree with your editorial of last week contemning the Extra-Curricular Committee's failure to approve the amendment to the P A. constitution recommending that the editor be given ultimate responsibility in matters pertaining to the paper as a whole .
 As the past editor of the STUDENT, I was partially responsible for the initiation of the amendments . I was partly responsible for this article .
 Ideally, no conflict should arise in the operation of the two major branches of the paper, the editorial and the business . The two are relatively autonomous. The editorial and business are relatively independent .
 The photography department, for example, has a budget, and is responsible to the business manager for it . Yet the editorial staff assigns the pictures .
 Last semester the business manager refused to release funds for expenses incurred while taking pictures of the fallout shelter, failing to realize that the responsibility for the content of the paper lay with the editor-in-chief .
 The two offices do occasionally conflict; when they do, only then is it necessary for someone to make a decision affecting both . Thus the two offices sometimes conflict, and only then, is the decision being made .
 Few businessmen, requiring an immediate decision, or any decision, on something involving their business would consider asking someone unfamiliar with the business to make the decision . Few businesses could survive with two presidents .
 Decisions have to be made, and someone must ultimately be held responsible for making them . Decisions must be made and someone has to be responsible for them .
 In the case of the STUDENT, I was held responsible by subscribers who were not receiving their papers, and by the faculty who failed to get copies delivered to them . Yet I was unable to rectify these mistakes because I was not authorized to invade the sanctity of the business section
 This, however, would set a precedent for faculty control of student organizations . This would be the first time faculty control has been granted to students .
 I could have requested special meetings of the P.A., (perhaps two or three a week), which would usually aggravate the problem . I could also request special meetings (perhaps 2 or three) a week, which would normally aggravate .
 Neither the faculty nor the majority of the P.A. know much about the daily running of the STUDENT, nor should they. Neither the staff nor faculty members know much of the daily run of the student body .
 Large boards are notoriously inefficient when it comes to making decisions . And large boards are notorious for being inefficient when they make decisions . This is the case for the U.S. government .
 Editorin-chief should be given responsibility on matters involving both the business and editorial sections . The paper which reaches students, not Wall Street rating, is most significant .
 The Extra-Curricular Committee did not query me on the practical operation of the paper . I was asked by the committee to explain how the paper was run .

 The proposed proctor councils would be concerned with only the specific problems and requirements of the men's and women's sides of campus . Proctor councils will be concerned only with specific problems .
 The Student Senate would relieve these two bodies of matters concerning the entire student body . Students would be able to function more effectively in their own particular area, says the Senate .
 At the present time, a fantastic amount of red tape is envolved in making any decisions which would affect all-student functions . Red Tape Prevails at the moment .
 "Stu-G and Stu-C drain away the effectiveness of each body. Countless linkage meetings, and . repetitious discussions, and repetitious . discussions in Stu .G and C drain away effectiveness of the bodies, says Stu.C .

 This amendment was discussed for several weeks among the P.A. members, the STUDENT staff, and the Extra-Curricular Activities Committee . This amendment would allow students to opt out of participating in the program .
 At no time during this period did I say that I was in favor of this amendment. "I'm not sure if I'm going to support this amendment," he says. "At no time I'm in favor"
 I was strongly opposed to the amendment, Mr. Ross said . Mr Ross said in meetings with Dean Boyce, Mr Nelson, and Mr Ross, he said . The amendment would have been a constitutional amendment .
 It was, therefore, a false assumption on the Editor's part when he stated that I was in favor of the amendment, he said . The Editor's comments were contrary to what he had said .
 In my opinion the proposed amendment was not the solution to a more efficiently run organization . In his opinion, I think the amendment would not be the solution for a more efficient organization .
 The original P.A. constitution purposely avoided giving ""ultimate responsibility"" to the editor . The original constitution was written to give the editor "ultimate responsibility"
 The fact that a personality conflict arose this past year involving editor and business manager does not merit a revision of the constitution . It's not necessary to revise the constitution, the editor says .
 The P.A. permitted this conflict to get out of hand instead of taking steps to correct it . "The P.E. permitted it to get so far out of control that it was not addressed by the authorities," said the mayor .
 In the future it would appear that the P.A. should have authority to meet the responsibility of solving such an issue rather than propose amendments .
 Robert J Lanz '65 was a member of the Committee for the University of Cambridge . The Committee has not been able to explain how it has been run in the past .

 Betty Anne Little, outgoing president of Stu-G, has expressed the opinion that the differing views of these two organizations would have to compromise in order to do the best thing for the campus . Little says the differing opinions of the two organizations should be balanced .
 This would also give more students a chance to participate in student government affairs . This would give students a better chance to be involved in student affairs .
 It has been pointed out that much talent is wasted on the women's side of campus . Much talent has been wasted on women's sides of campus in recent years .
 Some girls may have an interest in how student affairs are handled, but they would rather not participate in Student Senate . Some girls would rather rather not spend a major part of their time in Stu-G .
 The Student Senate can only be as valuable as next year's students make it . Next year's Senate will only be able to be valuable if it is successful, says Sen. John McCain .
 Some see it as a merging of equal number of men and women . Others see it only as merging of equals working on all-campus activities .
 Students want changes and are willing to work hard for them, things can be accomplished, says student leader .
 The administration and faculty, by supporting the Student Senate, have proven their concern with student attitudes, all kinds . The Senate has proven its concern with students' attitudes toward all kinds of attitudes .
 Those students who claim Bates's students are apathetic will have a golden opportunity to disproven, stated one strong supporter of the school .
 The success of this success will necessitate active interest by the entire campus . This should be shown through activities, student opinion polls, student publications, and personal initiative .
 Student Support is essential for students to have Student Senate . If students want to be Student Senate they should support it, they should be willing to support it .
 If they don't want it, don't care about it, or want to support it, they should not vote for it . This would only mean failure. If they want it or don't like it, it would mean failure, they shouldn't vote for .
 A great deal of time has been spent in preparing the Student Senate for the student body, a great deal has been wasted because of lack of support . The Student Senate is a vital part of the university's student experience .

 The system will fail without fuel. However, however good the machinery, it will fail if fuel is not enough .
 Life in a college is not a product of its buildings, budget, or machinery of its government . It rests on those who occupy the buildings, use the budget, and operate the machinery .
 The institution of the Student Senate is by all means a step forward, but we must not forget that it is we who make the step, and we must continue to walk . — Peter d'Errico '65. "We need to walk"
 Students of Bates College establish a Student Senate Constitution . The Constitution is intended to encourage the formulaton of responsible opinion .
 Article I Name The name of this organization shall be the Bates College Student Senate . Bates College's Student Senate will be the name of the Bates college Student Senate.
 Sophomore class, one man and one woman from Freshman class, and the Chairmen of the . Men's and Women's . Councils as voting members .
 To encourage the development of a campus attitude which stimulates intellectual freedom and concern . To seek effective communication among members of the college community; To seek for all students justice and the enjoyment of individual rights .
 To hold at least one meeting of the Senate each month of the college year; To have the responsibility for the allotment of its funds; To appoint a student to fill any vacancy in its membership which may arise; To attempt to coordinate the decisions of the Men's and Women's Council
 The Senate shall not have the power to alter, add, or void any section of the Women's Honor System . The Senate will not be able to alter or void sections of the system .
 The Dean of Men, the Dean of Women, faculty advisers, faculty members and administration offiicials on appropriate matters . Shall confer with the dean of men and women on matters such as sexual assault .
 Shall represent student opinion and act in the best interest of the students with consideration for the general policy of the college . Shall represent the student opinion .
 The Senate in cooperation with the four classes (and such All-Campus organizations as may elect to be included) shall secure each year nominations for the All-College Election .
 Nominees for the Senate will be those students who present a petition of forty signatures on an official form secured at the office of the Dean of Men . Nomineees will be students with forty signatures from a petition .
 In the primaries, a maximum of eight senior women, six junior women, and four sophomore women receiving the highest number of votes, shall be selected as candidates by the women . The women will be able to choose the candidates for the general election .
 The Senate, the four classes (and such All-Campus organizations as may elect to be included) shall conduct each year on the Monday before Spring Vacation a general college election .
 One week from the date of return to campus after Spring Vacation, an election of President and Vice-President shall be conducted by the outgoing Senate . The outgoing Senate will conduct the election of the President and vice-President .
 All registered students of Bates College may vote for the President of the Senate . Bates College students may also vote for a candidate for the position of president of the senate .
 During the interim period, those Senators desiring to be elected to the Presidency shall campaign. During the Interim Period, those seeking to be . elected to . President shall campaign for the Senate .
 Before final action is taken by either committee, the student shall have the opportunity to be heard by the committee . The student must also have an opportunity to speak to the committee before the decision is made .
 Any decisions or recommendations reached by either of these two standing committees shall be presented to the Committee on Student Conduct by the chairman of the committee involved . The chairman of each committee will be the chairman .
 No evidence presented before either of the Senate judicial committees or the Committee on Student Conduct shall be reported outside these bodies . The Senate judicial committee will not be used to report evidence presented outside of this body .
 Article VII Funds of the Senate Dues of $.75 per semester shall be collected from each student as part of the Student Activities Fee . Funds are collected from students as part bf the Student Activity Fee . Article VII funds will be collected by students at the University of Cambridge .
 A referendum shall be initiated by a vote of twothirds approval of the Senate members or a petition signed by one-tenth of the Student Body . A referendum should be initiated with the approval of twithirds of Senate members .
 A referendum must require a vote by secret ballot of three-fifths approval of the registered Student Body to be binding on the Senate . A referendum shall require a . vote by . secret ballot to be . binding on . the Senate.
 A question for a referendum must be appropriately posted at least five days before the Student Body is asked to vote . A referendum question for students must be posted five days prior to the student body voting .
 Amendments must be initiated by a vote of twothirds approval of the Senate members or a petition signed by one-tenth of the Student Body . Amendments may be initiated with a vote by the Senate or by a petition by one of the students .
 An amendment would require a vote by secret ballot of three-fifths approval of the registered Student Body to become effective . An amendment shall require a . vote by . secret ballot to become a . effective .
 Amendments must be appropriately posted at least five days before the Student Body is asked to vote . Amendments to be posted five days prior to the vote must be posted .
 The proctors of the dormitory in which the student resides shall be asked to serve as non-voting members of the Judicial Committee . Amendments to Article VII are subject to the approval of the Board of Trustees .
 The President, with the approval of the Senate, may appoint such other committees as are deemed necessary . The Senate may also appoint other committees .
 The Senate may approve any registered student for membership on standing or special committees . The Senate can also approve registered students for membership in standing committees .
 Faculty advisors will be designated by the Senate with the approval of the Extra-Curricular Activities Committee . Faculty advisors shall be designated . The Senate has the power to name advisors .
 The Dean of Men and the Dean of Women shall be faculty advisors, ex-officio . The dean of men and the dean of women shall be advisors to the faculty .
 "Robert's Rules of Order, Revised" shall be the parliamentary guide of the Senate . Article II rules of Order are the Senate's rules of order .
 Amendments to the By-Laws shall require a vote of twothirds approval of the Senate members . Article III Amendments Amendments are required to be approved by the Senate . The amendment to the Constitution is required by the majority of the House of Representatives .
 The men of Bates College established a constitution in order to act in the interest of the men of the college . The constitution was intended to help in establishing an atmosphere .
 This Constitution does not include those duties for which the Council members, acting as proctors in the men's dormitories, are responsible to the administration of the College . This Constitution shall concern the Council .
 The name of this organization shall be the Men's Council of Bates College . Article I Name: The name is Bates College's Men's council .
 Dues of $.25 per semester shall be collected from each man as part of the Student Activities Fee . Each man must pay $25 a semester to be collected by the university .
 The Council shall also have the responsibility of helping Freshmen adjust themselves to their new environment and to explain the relation that they have to the College and the upperclassmen .
 The Student Senate has the power to act in all matters pertaining solely to the interests of the men . To meet at appropriate intervals, or at the request of the Chairman, or . at the . request of . the Student Senate, To have the power . to act .
 The Chairman shall preside at all meetings; appoint committees as the need arises, be a voting member of the Student Senate, and preside as chairman of the Men's Judiciary Committee . The Vice-Chairman shall assume the duties of the Chairman in his absence . The Secretary Treasurer shall
 The men of the Student Senate (including the Chairman of the Men's Council) shall comprise the men's Proctor Selection Committee . The committee will be the Men of the Students' Proctor selection Committee .
 Committee will secure applications for proctorships after mid-term vacation in the second semester . Committee will also secure applications to proctorhips .
 Rec. ommendations for proctor appointments will be made to the Dean of Men not later than May SIX BATES STUDENT, MAY 1 .
 The Men's Proctor Selection Committee, shall be candidates for the office of Chairman of the Men's Council . The committee will select candidates for a position to be the Chairman .
 An election committee pointed by the president of the Student Senate will be respon sible for conducting the election prior to the beginning of the fi nal examination period at the end of the spring term .
 Members of this committee will be selected from the male membership of the student Senate . Members will have to be chosen from male members of the Senate . The committee will also have to include the student senate .
 The candidate receiving the largest number of votes cast by the registered male students shall be the Chairman and the runner-up shall be Vice-Chairman . The candidate receiving the largest number of votes will be the chairman .
 The Secretary Treasurer shall be elected by majority vote of the incoming proctors . This elec tion shall take place prior to the beginning of the final examination period following selection of proctors for the ensuing year .
 A referendum must be initiated by a vote of twothirds approval of the Men's Council or a petition signed by one-tenth of the men students . A referendum shall be initiated .
 A referendum requires a vote by secret ballot of three-fifths approval of the men students to be binding on the Council . A referendum shall require a vote in secret ballot by secret .
 A question for referendum must be appropriately posted at least five days before the men are asked to vote . A referendum question for the men must be posted five days in advance of the vote .
 Amendments must be initiated by a vote of two-thirds approval of the Men's Council or a petition signed by one-tenth of the men students . Amendment must be appropriately posted at least five days before the men are asked to vote . An amendment must require a vote by secret ballot
 No amendment shall be made to the Men's Council Constitution which shall alter the Council's relationship to the Student Senate . No amendment to the constitution will alter the relationship between the council and the student senate .
 The women's constitution was created by Bates College women's council . It was created to foster the ideals of Bates College and to develop wide-spread responsibility .
 The Honor System provides a common ground for the organization of corporate living to the mutual advantage of students and faculty . Students and faculty are encouraged to use the Honor System to improve their living experiences .
 Bates relies upon us to obey the fundamental rules for our own welfare and protection . We pledge our full efforts to make ourselves active participants in this organization and to avail ourselves .
 The name of this organization shall be the Women's Council of Bates College . Article I Name shall be this organization's name .
 The Women's Council shall consist of a Chairman, the presidents of the women's dormitories and the president of the Women's Uniorv and the first vice-president of Page Hall . Article II Membership and Funds Section I Membership, The . Women's . Council will consist of
 The Women's Council shall take office on the fourth Wednesday following All-College elections and shall serve for one year . Members of the Women's council shall take .
 Funds, Dues of $1.25 per semester shall be collected from each woman as part of the Student Activity Fees . Funds will be collected by each woman from each student . Funds are collected from the student Activity Fees and will be used to pay tuition .
 The Women's Council shall be responsible for the allotment of its funds . It will take up responsibility for the allocation of funds .
 Additional meetings shall be called at the discretion of the Chairman or at the request of four Council members . Additional meetings will be called in the future .
 To act as chairman of the Women's Judiciary Committee of the Student Senate of the University of California, he will serve as chairman .
 The Vice-Chairman shall assume the duties of the Chairman in her absence . The vice-chairman will assume the role of the chairman in the Chairman .
 To submit a copy of the minutes to the Student Senate and the Women's Council advisors, please submit your own copy of them .
 There shall be a Nominating Committee of eight women consisting of the Chairman of the Women's Council, ex-officio . A representative from the Senior class, a representative from Freshman class; two representatives from Junior class; three representatives from Sophomore class, one to be elected from
 These class representatives shall be elected by their own class members after two Seniors, four Juniors, six Sophomores, six sophomores and two Freshmen have been nominated by means of a primary ballot .
 The Nominating Committee shall appoint the House Presidents and VicePresidents who shall serve as proctors in their respective dorms . Two incoming Seniors who have served as members of the Women's Council during their junior year will be nominated for the Chairmanship . Names of these nominees shall be
 To manage all financial business in her dormitory with the approval of the House President . House President to manage financial matters with approval of House President.
 The House President shall call a general meeting once a week at which time information from the Women's Council shall be presented and dormitory business discussed . Each student is allowed two unexcused ab sences a semester from House Meetings . The House president must call a General Meeting once a
 The third and each succeeding unexcused absence within a semester should be re-ported to House Council by the woman involved . House Council should re-portport the third, each succeeding excess absence within a semester .
 Each House Council, except those housing senior women only, shall be composed of a Chairman who is the House President . A Vice-Chairman is the other proctor; one representative from the junior class; and one Representative from the sophomore class .
 At the first House Meeting the women shall be asked to consider possible House Council Representatives in their class . The women's first House meeting will be held at the beginning of the year .
 The women shall elect their class representatives by means of rating sheets . A formal vote shall be taken two days later to determine House Council membership .
 The qualifications for House Council membership shall be drawn up in each dormitory by the women . The qualifications are drawn up by women at the women's dormitory .
 Election to and representation on House Council in senior dormitories shall be approved by the Women's Council . Election to or representation on . House . Council in . senior dorms shall be . approved .
 Summer study and recreation in the stimulating climate of one of our country's finest vacation regions . Combine summer study and . recreation in one of the nation's finest summer destinations .
 To keep records of each meeting for purposes of efficiency and to destory these records at the end of each semester . These records will be destoryed at the beginning of the semester .
 A woman incurs a case for infringement of any rule enumerated in the By-Laws . A case is made against a woman who infringes on any rule listed in the law .
 She may state her case in writing and give it to any one of the House Council members . She may also state it in writing .
 She may state her reason for breaking the rule if she wishes and whether or not she would like a reminder . She may also say she wants to be reminded of the rule .
 She must indicate how she will take care of her case if she does not request a reminder . She may come before the entire House Council and state her case and explain her reasons if she wishes .
 In the event of a frequent or flagrant offender the proctors may intervene . Proctors will intervene in the case of the offender .
 Give a firm warning to the woman, Request that she come before the House Council for disciplinary action . Discuss the problem with the Dean of Women and/or the Women's Council . Ask that the woman come before her House Council .
 Women's Council or petition signed by one-tenth of all registered women students . Petition signed by 1-10% of students signed by petition signed . Women's council is the largest group of registered students .
 A referendum must require a vote by secret ballot of three-fifths approval of all registered women students to be binding on the Council .
 Decisions of disciplinary cases are not subject to appeal . Decisions are made in accordance with the law and are subject to no appeal .
 A question for referendum must be appropriately posted at least five days before, the women are asked to vote . A referendum question must be published at least 5 days before the women vote .
 Amendments must be initiated by vote of two-thirds approval of the Women's Council or a petition signed by one-tenth of all registered women students . Amendments shall be appropriately posted at least five days before the women students arc asked to vote . An amendment shall require a vote by secret
 The By-Laws shall be amended by a vote of twothirds approval of the Womens Council . The By Law is amended by the vote of thirds approval .
 No amendment shall be made to the Women's Council Constitution which shall alter the Council's relationship to the Student Senate . No amendment to the Constitution will alter the relationship between the Council and the student senate .

 There are several minimum requirements which the U.S. must consider in dealing with other powers . The United States must consider these minimum requirements .

 A total eclipse of the sun will occur on July 20 and its shadow will cross Maine from Quebec beginning at 5:41m. The eclipse will take place at 5.41m . The sun's shadow will pass over the state of Maine from Maine .
 The eclipse will last for four minutes and pass into the Atlantic at 5:45. It will be the first time it will pass over the Atlantic . It will last four minutes .
 At any one point on the earth a total eclipse of the sun is visible only about three times in 1,000 years . In one calendar year two eclipses must occur and five are possible . Total eclipse of sun occurs at any point in 1.000 years, although in one calendar
 There will be only five total solar eclipses visible from anywhere in North America from now until 2025 . Only five total eclipses will be visible from North America until 2025.
 This eclipse of the sun will occur when the moon passes directly between the sun and the earth so that the moon's shadow is cast upon the earth . This eclipse will be the first of its kind to take place on Earth's surface .
 Solar eclipses do not occur each time the moon is new; the moon's shadow passes either above or below the earth . This always occurs at new moon, but solar eclipses always occur at new .
 Solar eclipses may be partial, total, or annular, depending on the size of the shadow cone falling on the earth . Partial, total or total eclipses can be seen in some cases .
 They are visible as total over a very narrow band of the earth at any one time . They may last from a few seconds to eight minutes .

 Krzynowek had it in the clutch and escaped any serious damage . Although he was in trouble on several occasions, he was not in danger of serious injury .
